div.head: The Brookville Society of Natural History
div.p: Following the decline of Robert Owen's experimental society at New Harmony , the state of Indiana was void of organizations devoted to scientific study and research. Several associations were attempted throughout the state, but their influence was entirely local. None of them attained reputation, prominence, or accomplishment comparable to that of the Brookville Society of Natural History, organized in 1881 by Amos W. Butler.

The founding of the society was inspired by Rufus Haymond, the first productive zoologist in Indiana after Thomas Say, "Father of American Zoology," who died at New Harmony in 1834.1 Haymond was born near Clarksburg, Virginia , on June 5, 1805, and completed his training for the medical profession at the Philadelphia Medical College. During the summer of 1826, the young doctor journeyed to Brookville to visit a distant relative and decided to start his practice there. His motive for staying is not easily understood since the settlement of Brookville was suffering a severe economic depression at that time. The most probable explanation is that he had a keen interest in nature and found the region an ideal locality for the exercise of this interest.

During the years of his residence at Brookville , Haymond recorded his observations on nature in two publications. The first of these was a treatise on ornithology, titled "Birds of Southeastern Indiana." It was published in the Proceedings of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia
in 1856. The second was published in the First Annual Report of the Geological Survey of Indiana in 1869, when Haymond was selected as assistant to Edward T. Cox, State Geologist. Haymond
1 Will E. Edington, "There Were Giants in Those Days," Proceedings of the Indiana Academy of Science ( Indianapolis , Indiana, 1891-), XLIV (1935), 27; Barton Warren Evermann, "A Century of Zoology in Indiana, 1816–1916," Proceedings of the Indiana Academy of Science. 1916 (1917), 189–224.
reported on the physical geography of Franklin County and included a list of its mammals and birds.

Haymond's publications were valuable, they brought him deserved attention as a scientist, but his contribution as an inspiration to others of the community was of more lasting worth. That he recognized the significance which his influence might have was indicated in the introduction of the speech he presented before the Franklin Lyceum at Brookville about 1850. He said,

quote.p: If I should be so fortunate in the remarks I shall make this evening as to persuade a single individual among you to turn his attention to the study and investigation of natural history or the operations of Nature displayed in her works which surround us at every step we take upon the earth, I shall feel myself well repaid for the small amount of time and labor required in the preparation of this address.2

div.p: In fact, Haymond did inspire many. One of the persons most influenced by him was Amos W. Butler, born at Brookville on October 1, 1860. As a youth, Butler became very much interested in nature and before he was sixteen, he was specializing in zoology. He wrote many years later, "Books were scarce. I soon learned of the interest in Natural History of Dr. Rufus Haymond. He was very helpful to me in acquiring a knowledge of the more common animals."3 Further development of Butler 's scientific thinking was evolved through his formal educational training. When he went to Brookville College, he was a student of John P. D. John, who was a professor of mathematics. After a year at Brookville College, Butler attended Hanover College in southern Indiana and was a student of John W. Coulter, one of Indiana's most prominent botanists. Finally, Butler attended Indiana University, where he was a student of Daniel Kirkwood, distinguished astronomer, and Richard Owen, noted naturalist and geologist. At Indiana University, however, Butler became so obsessed with his study of birds that he neglected the classics and was debarred from graduation.4

list.item: 2 E. R. Quick, "Dr. Rufus Haymond," Bulletin of the Brookville Society of Natural History, No. 3 (College Corner, Ohio , 1888), 21–25.
3 Amos W. Butler, "Early History of the Indiana Academy of Science," Proceedings of the Indiana Academy of Science, XXXIII (1924), 14.

4 David Starr Jordan , The Days of a Man (2 vols., Yonkers-on-Hudson, New York , 1922), I, 240; Edington, "There Were Giants in Those Days," Proceedings of the Indiana Academy of Science, XLIV, 32–37; Marcus Ward Lyon, Jr., "Amos William Butler," Proceedings of the Indiana Academy of Science, XLVII (1938), 21–25; Barton Warren Evermann, "Amos William Butler," The Audubon Year Book, 1932 (n.p., n.d.), 5–19.

div.p:
When Butler returned to Brookville , he found a number of persons who shared his interests. Notable among these men was a Presbyterian minister, David R. Moore, who was born at Rising Sun, Indiana, on January 9, 1850. He graduated from Miami University in 1871, Lane Theological Seminary in 1875, and Princeton Theological Seminary in 1878.5 Intensely alert toward all things scientific, he stimulated others in that direction. To promote greater interest, he invited those who wished to expand and exchange their information to meet at his home for informal discussions. The group held occasional lectures in the Presbyterian church, and the attendance became so large that Butler conceived the idea of a formal organization. After discussing the venture with Moore, Butler and Moore suggested the plan to the group at one of the meetings. The proposal was met with such enthusiasm that a special meeting was called on January 12, 1881, at Moore's residence. At that meeting action was taken immediately to elect officers. Moore was elected president, Charles F. Goodwin, a prominent young banker, vice-president, Butler , secretary, Edgar R. Quick, editor of the
Franklin Democrat, correspondent, and John T. Rehme, treasurer. The new president appointed a committee, consisting of Butler , Frank Barton, and Quick, to draft a constitution.

At the second meeting, which was held on January 21, 1881, the organization decided to call itself the Brookville Society of Natural History, and it adopted a constitution. It specified departments and chose curators for each department. It decided to hold meetings every second Friday evening in the society's room over Emerson B. Rockafellar's stove store. It established the ideals of the society in the prospectus of its constitution, a portion of which is repeated here as follows:
Special features augur for the society a useful and brilliant future. The reputation of certain persons of the past generation for original research and eminence in scientific studies have already brought the name of Brookville upon National Scientific records, and some members of the society have already acquired notable records as collectors and students. The society will make the county a study and will aim to such discoveries as will not only be pleasurable to its members but of profit to the people of the county. It will seek also to establish a museum that will be a practical exhibit of its work and a credit to
5 Amos W. Butler, "David R. Moore," Proceedings of the Indiana Academy of Science, XLII (1933), 18–19.
the county. It will gather together with the Smithsonian Institution and other leading scientific societies of the country, and number among its honorary members distinguished professors of science and instructors of Natural History.6

The society offered its services to the public and asked that it be made the depository for all material which might be included in a museum to benefit the public. It also scheduled a number of formal lectures. Among the prominent lecturers who addressed the group were David Starr Jordan , professor of zoology at Indiana University, John M. Coulter. David Worth Dennis, professor of biology at Earlham College, John P. D. John, who had become president of Moore's Hill College, Barton W. Evermann, prominent naturalist, and Stanley Coulter, botanist and conservationist.

The society became extremely active. One year after its founding Butler and Quick published several papers ill the Journal of the Cincinnati Society of Natural History. Also in 1882 the society revised Haymond's report of 1869 and published it in the Historical Atlas of Franklin County
. Quick, who had charge of preparing a list of mamals, was praised at the conclusion of his list by the following statement: "Through Mr. Quick's liberality, specimens have been placed in the museums of the Zoological Society of London , the Royal Society of Berlin, and the Cincinnati Society of Natural History."7 And in the same year the entire society was encouraged by this comment: "The society has already accomplished much, and bids fair to be one of the most successful in the West."8 Citizens of Brookville and its outlying regions co-operated particularly well in donating specimens to the society, and its museum grew to sizable proportions. The Brookville National Rank donated the parlor of the Walz mansion to the society for use as a museum and meeting room.

Quick published an account of the society's progress in his paper, the
Franklin Democrat, in March, 1883. He wrote, "On this second anniversary of our birth, we congratulate ourselves and thank our friends that we have so far exceeded our highest dreams and today stand without an equal in the
6 Constitution and By-Laws of the Brookville Society of Natural History, from the scrapbook of George W. Homsher. The scrapbook is now in the Brookville Public Library, Brookville , Indiana.
7 Historical Atlas of Franklin County , Indiana ( Chicago , 1882), 9.
8 Ibid., 97.
state of Indiana. Our collection has increased to thousands of specimens and our library is now approaching its 1000th volume."9

The society published its first bulletin in 1885. Its preface read as follows:
The Brookville Society of Natural History was organized in the month of February, 1881, and one year from the date of its organization was incorporated under the laws of Indiana …. What has been accomplished justifies the endeavors now made to issue a Bulletin which shall proclaim the worth of the Society, and afford such a medium of literary exchange as will bring it into relationship with scientists and scientific institutions all over the world. As may be seen from the list herein published, all departments of study in natural history are represented, and measures taken from the pursuit of research in all, under the supervision of competent curators. The local field of the Society presents the necessary material for each and every department to an extent in variety and abundance exceeding any other portion of the state.10

Long before 1885, however, Butler began carrying on activities beyond the limits of the society. He attended the American Association for the Advancement of Science in August, 1881, which met at Cincinnati . The program and the congeniality of the group left a deep impression on him. In the following year, he attended the meeting held at Montreal where he increased his contacts and began to visualize the possibility of a state organization. He started to correspond with all the prominent scientists of the state in order to obtain their opinions of such an organization. From most of these men he received approval and encouragement. Later, at the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science at Ann Arbor in 1885, Butler and other scientists from Indiana held a conference and determined that the Brookville Society of Natural History, as the most active scientific society in the state, should call a meeting and prepare a program for the purpose of organizing the state society. After he returned to Brookville, Butler brought the matter before the Brookville society, and a committee, consisting of Butler , Moore, and s. P. Stoddard, was appointed to make all arrangements for a gathering of the Indiana scientists.

list.item:
9 E. R. Quick, "Scientific Notes," Brookville , Indiana,
Franklin Democrat, March 1, 1883.
10 " Brookville Society of Natural History," in the Bulletin of the Brookville Society of Natural History, No. 1 ( Richmond , Indiana, 1885), preface.

div.p:
The meeting was held in the Marion County Courthouse on December 29, 1885, with John P. D. John as temporary chairman. The Forty persons in attendance adopted a permanent organization with a constitution and by-laws an? elected as president David Starr Jordan , president of Indian;; University. Butler , Moore, Quick, and Stoddard, of the Brookville society, became charter members of the new state organization, which was named the Indiana Academy of Science. The academy held its first field meeting May 20–22, 1886, at, Brookville , with the Brookville Society of Natural History as its host, and they spent the first day among the hills along the east fork of the Whitewater River. Butler wrote
In the deep water above the ford the members of the Academy went swimming. There, as Dr. Dennis said, the members saw each other as they were, a thing they had never done before. There Jordan climbed a rock just below the surface of the water and formally christened the Academy. "For," said he, "when the members of the Academy can all go swimming together, it is bound to be a success."11
Thus the Brookville Society of Natural History performed the important function of being the direct causative agent for the founding of the Indiana Academy of Science, which has become the largest organization of its sort in the country.

Meanwhile, the Brookville Society of Natural History had published its second bulletin in 1886. The society, however, lost two of the stimulants for the organization. They were Moore, who left Brookville in 1886, and Haymond, who died on July 29, 1886. Gradually the fibers of the society pulled apart. For five years it had been an extremely active and valuable organization, but it lost impetus and distintegrated rather rapidly as more emphasis and attention were given to the broader scope of the Indiana Academy of Science. Probably the main cause of its distintegration was that the constitution stated that any person in Franklin County was eligible to be a resident member of the organization; consequently, the society gained members who were not scientifically trained. The third and last of the bulletins of the Brookville Society of Natural History appeared in 1888. Within the following three years most of the material in the museum was returned to the donors or dispersed in other ways. The last meeting was held in 1890 or 1891 despite conscientious efforts for its revival.

list.item:
11
Butler , "Early History of the Indiana Academy of Science," Proceedings of the Indiana Academy of Science, XXXIII, 15–18. There is an Amos W. Butler Collection in the Indiana University Library, Bloomington , Indiana. Editor.

div.head: Fiscal Objection to Statehood in Indiana
div.p: Opposition to increased tax burdens was the principal objection to statehood when Indiana was admitted to the Union in 1816.1 According to the Ordinance of 1787, which although dealing specifically with the Northwest Territory served as the model for most subsequent territorial governments, a new territory was launched as a first or nonrepresentative stage of government without any popular voice in the selection of territorial officials.2 This level continued until an increased population made possible an advance to the second or representative stage of government with a popularly elected House of Representatives.3 Statehood was the final step in the transition from territory to equal membership in the Union. As the territorial frontier swept westward, the democratic impulse, especially strong in the frontier area, soon made the process decidedly more democratic.4

The Northwest Territory at first included all of the present states of Ohio , Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin , and the eastern half of Minnesota and was governed as a non-representative territory from 1788 until 1798 when the area entered the second or representative stage by proclamation
1 This conclusion was also reached by Charles Kettleborough (ed.), Constitution Making in Indiana (3 vols., Indiana Historical Collections, I, II, and XVII, Indianapolis , Indiana, 1916, 1930), I, xvi: "Chief argument advanced in opposition to the assumption of Statehood was the expense and the increased taxation."
2 The 1787 Ordinance is in Francis N. Thorpe (comp.), The Federal and State Constitutions … and Other Organic Laws … (7. vols., Washington , 1909), II, 957–962; and also Kettleborough, Constitution Making in Indiana, I, 26–33. Andrew C. McLaughlin, The Confederation and the Constitution, 178.1–1789 (American Nation Series, 28 vols., New York , 1904–1925, edited by Albert B. Hart), X (1905), 120–122, indicates that the Ordinance served as a model for other territories.
3 Kettleborough, Constitution Making in Indiana, I, 29: "So soon as there shall be 5,000 free male inhabitants of full age in the district, upon giving proof thereof to the governor, they shall receive authority, with time and place, to elect representatives from their counties or townships to represent them in the General Assembly. …" The act of 1800 establishing the Indiana Territory, however, provided for transition to the second stage "whenever satisfactory evidence shall be given to the Governor thereof that such is the wish of a majority of the freeholders…." as stated in ibid., 42.
4 Ibid., 48, 56–57, 38–59, 73–77; and Annals of Congress, 10 Cong., 1 Sess., 2834; 10 Cong., 2 Sess., 1821–1822; 11 Cong., 3 Sess., 1347–1348; 14 Cong., 1 Sess., 459–461, 1841–1844, for laws of Congress making the Indiana process more democratic. Concerning other territories see Thorpe, The Federal and State Constitutions, passim.
of Governor Arthur St. Clair.5 This change added considerably to the cost of government, and very shortly inhabitants of the western region, mainly French, sent memorials to Congress protesting the heavy territorial taxes arising from the transition.6 They beseeched Congress to return them to the less expensive, although nonrepresentative first stage, and their prayer was answered by the establishment of Indiana Territory in 1800. The parent area west of a line beginning at the north bank of the Ohio River opposite the mouth of the Kentucky , thence to Fort Recovery and due north to Canada , was included in the new territory.7 Indiana then comprised nearly all of the present Indiana, the western half of Michigan , all of Illinois and Wisconsin , and the eastern half of Minnesota .

Four years later Indiana advanced to the representative level, with its added fiscal burdens, and history repeated itself with the people in the regions of Detroit and Kaskaskia praying Congress for a return to the nonrepresentative stage by the creation of new territories.8
Michigan was organized
5 Clarence E. Carter (comp. and ed.), The Territorial Papers of the United States
( Washington , 1934-), The Territory Northwest of the River Ohio , 1787–1803, III, 514–515, has a copy of the proclamation. The boundaries of the Northwest Territory were set forth in the Ordinance of 1787.
6 Concerning the increased cost see: Jacob Burnet, Notes on the Early Settlement of the Northwest Territory ( Cincinnati, Ohio , 1847), 301, 313; Clarence W. Alvord, The Illinois Country, 1673–1818 (The Centennial History of Illinois
, I, Springfield, Illinois , 1920), 406–407; William A. Rawles, Centralizing Tendencies in the Administration of Indiana ( Columbia University Studies in Political Science, XVII, No. 1, New York , 1903), 250. For the tax laws involved see Theodore C. Pease (ed.), The Laws of the Northwest Territory, 1788–1800 ( Illinois State Historical Library Collections, XVII,
Springfield, Illinois , 1925), 467–478, 478–494. The memorials are in Carter, The Territorial Papers of the United States
, III, 76–78 and VII, The Territory of Indiana, 1800–1810 (1939), 3–4.
7 For the law creating the new territory see:
United States Statutes at Large, II, 58–59; Annals of Congress, 6 Cong., 1 Sess., 1498–1500. For maps of territorial changes of this period see George Pence and Nellie C. Armstrong, Indiana Boundaries: Territory, State and County Indiana Historical Collections, XIX, Indianapolis , 1933), 137–147.
8 Memorial of the Citizens and Inhabitants of the Indiana Territory, Praying for the Interposition of Congress, to Relieve Them From Certain Embarrassments ( Washington City, 1804); Carter, The Territorial Papers of the United States
, VII, 227–231, 240–242, 140–145; Annals of Congress. 9 Cong., 1 Sess. 466–468: American State Papers: Documents, Legislative and Executive (38 vols., Washington , 1832–1861), Miscellaneous. XXXVII and XXXVIII (1834), XXXVII, 922; Carter, The Territorial Papers of the United States
, VII, 544–554.
as a separate territory in 1805, but the Illinois petitioners had to wait until 1809 for their separation.9

Indiana remained at the representative stage from late in 1804 until statehood was achieved in 1816, during which period the total territorial expenditures averaged approximately ten thousand dollars yearly.10 About two-thirds of this sum was paid from federal appropriations leaving one-third payable from territorial revenues. While at the nonrepresentative level, territorial costs had totaled about $5,700 annually with all but two hundred dollars being provided from the federal treasury.11

The meagerness of these totals, especially when the extent of the federal subsidy is considered, is indicative of the fiscal atmosphere in which Indiana became a state. It was generally understood that this federal support would be lost if territorial days were ended. while it was also recognized that statehood would result in added costs. The ensuing discussion has several references to these points of view. With this picture before us, the fiscal aspect of the statehood contest can be observed more nearly from the contemporary perspective and the movement cannot be properly understood in any other manner. Such objectivity is particularly hard to achieve in these days when fiscal expenditures have towered skyward until millions and even billions are spent with less caution and care than the founding fathers of Indiana spent thousands or even hundreds of dollars.12

By 1816, Indiana with a population of between seventy-five thousand and one hundred thousand was ripe for state
9
United States Statutes at Large, II, 309–310, 514–516.
10 Donald E’. Carmony, "Indiana Territorial Expenditures, 1800–1816," in the Indiana Maguzine of History ( Bloomington , Indiana, 1906-), XXXIX (1943), 261.
11 Ibid., 244–246, 261–262. Further details concerning territorial expenditures may be found in this article and in Donald F. Carmony, Indiana Public Finance, 1800–1826 (Ph.D. thesis, Indiana University, Bloomington , Indiana, 1940), 1–56.
12 Logan Esarey (ed.), Messayes and Letters of William Henry Harrison (2 vols., Indiana Historical Collections, VII and IX, Indianapolis , Indiana, 1922), I, 156–157, quoting Governor Harrison to the first representative Assembly in 1805 urging "the strictest frugality and economy" and advising that the government avoid drawing "from the people a single cent that can be dispensed with …." For other territorial economy see Carmony, Indiana Public Finance, 1800–1826, pp. 104–107.
hood.13 Indian resistance had been crushed during the War of 1812 and English influence around the Great Lakes had waned.14 Indiana was the first of six states to enter the Union in the half-dozen years beginning in 1816, and the spirit of nationalism reached a new peak causing membership in the Union to be viewed with patriotic pride.15

The Mississippi Valley was debtor to the Atlantic Seaboard and Europe, and its financial resources were limited even more than many contemporaries realized, but that frontier spirit of optimism and expansion which led to excessive land speculation and reckless ventures in banking and internal improvements often produced rosy forecasts of future fiscal affairs. The failure of the First State Rank of Indiana in the 1820's and the internal improvements debacle of the late thirties and early forties are appropriate Indiana illustrations of this frontier tendericy.16 Some Indiana taxpayers, however, preferred a prolongation of the territorial status to being "weaned" from the federal treasury but such raised their voices in vain.

As early as 1811, serious consideration was given to the question of statehood when in December, about one month after the Battle of Tippecanoe (which may have been the immediate spur to action), the Indiana Assembly approved a
13 Carter, The Territorial Papers of the United States , The Territory of Indiana, 1810–1816, VIII (1939), 364; Annals of Congress, 14 Cong., 1 Sess., 460; Kettleborough, Constitution Making in Indiana, I, 68–69. These sources indicate a total of nearly sixty-four thousand according to the territorial census of 1815, but there was a considerable increase in population between the taking of this census and the formal end of the territorial period on December 11, 1816.
14 Frederic L. Paxson, History of the American Frontier, 1763–1793 ( Boston , 1924), 178; Logan Esarey, A History of Indiana (2 vols., Fort
Wayne , Indiana, 1924), I, 228–229; Dan E. Clark, The West in American History ( New York , 1937), 217.
15 The other states were Illinois, Missouri, Alabama, Mississippi , and Maine . All "western" states except Maine which was also a frontier area. See the quotation from the Lexington , Indiana, Western Eagle, supported by footnote number. 26 following, for an example of the patriotic pride with which membership in the Union was viewed.
16 Logan Esarey, "Internal Improvements in Early Indiana," Indiana Historical Society, Publications ( Indianapolis , Indiana, 1895-), V (1915), 47–158. Also Logan Esarey, State Banking in Indiana, 1814–1873 (Indiana University Studies, No. 15, Bloomington , Indiana, 1912), passim. The Journals of the House and Senate for nearly any annual session of this period reflect this spirit in the messages of the governor and various committee reports.
memorial seeking statehood.17 Two members of the lower house expressed their disapproval saying:
That the inhabitants of the said Territory suffer no evils under their present form of government which would not be increased fourfold by an admission at this time into the union as an Independent state inasmuch as the people are not sufficiently numerous for such a state of things, having as appears by the late census but a few over Twenty four thousand inhabitants
Secondly: The Treasury of the said Territory is at present in such a miserable state of depression that Territorial paper is infinitely below par; and this too although the Tax on Land has hitherto exceeded all example, and has in fact been higher than the people are willing or can conveniently bear; and under a State Government our expenditures must be increased fourfold.18
Thirdly
Because under the existing Government of the Territory we enjoy nearly all the blessings and benefits of a State Government without the fourth of its expense inasmuch as although our executive possesses the sole power of appointment yet there is Scarce an instance of an officer whose appointment is not left to the nomination of the people. Decr 13th 1811
(JAMES DILL Signed (PETER JONES19
These two legislators objected to the increased taxation which would result from statehood, especially when the alternative was a liberal territorial regime which was very inexpensive to territorial taxpayers.

The memorial contained no fiscal clauses but reference to the increased population which was expected to follow statehood was probably linked with the hope of subsequently enjoying more favorable fiscal conditions through diffusion of tax burdens. Emphasis was placed upon the need for emancipation from the "Monarchal" form of territorial government, but it was a "principl, not men or measures" from which they sought liberation.20

list.item: 17 Journal of the House of Representatives of the Indiana Territory, 1811. See under date of December 11. Typed copies of the available territorial journals are in possession of the Indiana Historical Bureau, Indianapolis , Indiana.

18 The annual tax on land during territorial days varied from about one-fourth to one cent per acre. See Carmony, Indiana Public Finance, 1800–1826, pp. 75–77. The source indicated contains citations to the tax laws.

19 The protest is in Carter, The Territorial Papers of the United States
, VIII, 147–148.

20 The memorial is in ibid., 150–151; also in Louis B. Ewbank and Dorothy L. Riker (eds.), The Laws of Indiana Territory, 1809–1816 (Indiana Historical Collections, XX, Indianapolis , Indiana, 1934), 787–788.

div.p: General Johnston, who voted for the petition, wrote Indiana citizens hazarding the opinion that Congress would grant the prayer of the Assembly because of the reduction of congressional expenditures which would flow therefrom.21 Johnston was, no doubt, referring to the end of federal appropriations for certain territorial salaries and a contingent fund which would cease with statehood. His prediction was inaccurate, however, a select committee of the lower house of Congress, headed by Territorial Delegate Jonathan Jennings, reported a resolution favoring statehood whenever the population reached thirty-five thousand as determined by a territorial census.22

The War Of 1812 apparently checked and delayed agitation for statehood. During the years 1812 and 1813, the thoughts and efforts of the people of Indiana were beamed on defense from the Indians and their British allies, although by the end of 1814 the war clouds were dispersing and the immediate future promised a considerable impetus to population and fiscal resources. The Assembly provided for an 1815 territorial census to discover whether. the number of inhabitants totaled a minimum of sixty thousand as required for statehood by the Ordinance of 1787.23 In the summer of 1814, Waller Taylor, in announcing himself a rival for Jenning's position in Congress, rather gingerly advocated statehood: "as soon as the people shall think themselves able to support it, however, I shall expect instructions, and those instructions, whatever they may be, coming from a majority of the people, or from the Legislature, I shall punctually obey."24

The 1815 census, taken by the tax listers or assessors, disclosed a population of nearly sixty-four thousand.25 Newspapers within and without the territory viewed this count as opening the way to immediate statehood. The Western Eagle, recipient of the public printing patronage, proudly announced:
another manly link is about to be added to the bright chain of our glorious republic in the Territory of Indiana …. there is a charm,
21
Vincennes , Indiana, Western Sun, December 28, 1811.
22 For the committee report see Annuls of Congress, 12 Cong., 1 Sess, 1247; also in Kettleboruugh, Constitutional Making in Indiana, I, 66–67.
23 Ewbank and Riker, Laws of Indiana Territory, 1809–1816, pp. 585–588.
24
Vincennes , Indiana, Western Sun, June 23, 1812.
25 See footnote 13 above.
a political magic in the right of self government … that attracts our citizens to an independent state government in preference to a territorial establishment even partially at the expense of the Federal government. The Eagle cited the rapid development of Ohio in the preceding decade as ample illustration of the magic of statehood; here the flow of population had been greater than that of the Greeks over the Mediterranean World.26

On December 11, 1815, exactly one year before the formal admission of Indiana, the territorial house again approved a memorial for statehood and soon concurred in changes which the Council made therein.27 Jonathan Jennings, still territorial delegate and leader of the statehood movement, presented this memorial to the lower house of Congress where it was referred to a committee of which he was chairman. After some delay, perhaps arising partly from its association with a similar act for Mississippi , an Indiana Enabling Act was approved by President James Madison on April 19, 1816.28

While this measure was pending at Washington , Governor Thomas Posey, who had succeeded Harrison in 1813, wrote a personal letter to Secretary of State Monroe against statehood:
Some of our Citizens are very restless to go into a State government. I wish the people were well prepared for the measure, but I may say with propriety that at least two thirds, or three fourths, are not able to contribute but very little, if any thing to the Support of a State: and there is also a very great scarcety of talents, or men of such information as are necessary to fill the respective Stations, & offices of government. No doubt you have seen the memorial of the two Houses of our Legislature to Congress for the purpose of going into a State Government. If Congress should be so benevolent as to grant all ask'd
26
Lexington , Indiana, Western Eagle, October 28, 1815; Niles’ Weekly Register ( Baltimore , 1811–1837), VI (August 6, 1814), 394; ibid., IX (November 4, 1815), 171.
27 Journal of the House of Representatives of the Indiana Territory, 1815. See under date of December 11 and 12. Typed copy in the possession of the Indiana Historical Bureau. The memorial is in Ewbank and Riker, The Laws of Indiana Territory, 1809–1816, pp. 811–814; Lexington , Indians, Western Eagle. December 23, 1815; Vincennes , Indiana, Western Sun, January 27, 1816; Niles’ Weekly Register, IX, (January 20, 1816), 352–353; Kettleborough, Constitution Making in Indiana, I, 69–72.
28 Concerning the passage of this act through Congress see Annals of Congress, 14 Cong., 1 Sess., 408, 459–461, 1293, 1300, 1367, 1373, 31, 255, 274, 282, 312, 315. For the Enabling Act see
United States Statutes at Large, III, 289–291; Vincennes , Indiana, Western Sun, May 4, 3816; Kettleborough, Constitution Making in Indiana, I, 73–77.
for, there would be no other difficulty except the want of men of good informalion.29
The governor stated that three years would be soon enough to make the proposed transition and solicited the endorsement of Secretary Monroe for another three-year term as governor! Posey, no doubt, realized that his tenure was contingent on a prolongation of the territorial period and this perhaps fortified his position in regard to statehood, while such leaders as Jennings, who would probably gain political advancement, were inclined to soft-pedal the increased fiscal burdens which would result from statehood.30

"A Farmer of Knox County," more likely an associate of Governor Posey than a dirt farmer, anticipated the adoption of the Ènabling Act and warned his fellow citizens: "A state government! that would POW, and while the direct tax continues, cost us above thirty thousand dollars, in addition to the enormous expences that must accumulate to support a great increase of offices."31 Although "A Farmer" stressed the political disadvantages of statehood, most of what he penned was a severe indictment of Jennings. Later, "A Farmer of Knox County," perhaps the same as above, charged Jennings with the responsibility for the Enabling Act which he claimed was at the expense of and against the wishes of a large majority in Knox and adjoining counties.32 The statements of "A Farmer" support the thesis that the fiscal argument was the principal objection to statehood and their criticism of Jennings illustrates the importance attached to his leadership.

On the eve of the constitutional convention, at Corydon, The Cornucopia of the West wisely counseled that to assume the dignified position of a free and independent state would "require the exercise of a degree of fortitude, wisdom and
29 Thomas Posey to James Monroe, Jeffersonville , Indiana Territory, January 26, 1816, in Carter, The Territorial Papers of the United States
, VIII, 380. Also in Esarey, Messages and Letters of William Henry Harrison, II, 715, with some variations.
30 In 1816 Jennings was elected governor over Posey. The transition from territory to state lowered the governor's salary from two thousand to one thousand dollars annually. Previous discussion has indicated that during territorial days such salaries were paid from the federal treasury, however, statehood transferred such expense to the Indiana treasury.
31
Vincennes , Indiana, Western Sun, April 20, 1816.
32 Ibid., July 20, 1816. "Farmer" supported the election of Posey as governor in the ensuing August election.
economy…." It was urged that taxes be reduced and shackles be removed from industry.33 Contemporaries generally consider taxes "too high," but present day Hoosiers may well wonder what shackles then burdened industry. Apparently, the then odious excise taxes which the federal government had reluctantly revived during the war of 1812 were the target of this criticism.34

The most complete and best organized of the available statements against statehood came from the pen of "Republican" who addressed his thoughtful remarks "To The Citizens of Indiana." His identity is unknown but he was strongly opposed to Jennings. "Republican's" appeal appeared in the Western Sun about one week prior to the convening of the constitutional convention and may have been timed to influence the delegates to decide against framing a constitution as the next step on the road to statehood. "Republican" viewed the crisis as one which seldom occurred and confined his argument largely to the fiscal issue, making no other objection to statehood.

Although taxes in support of the territorial government were heavy, statehood would cause these burdens to be doubled,35 while by remaining a territory money could be saved to citizens where it was much needed in settling a new country. Indianans were urged to attend for a while to "the opening, clearing, and cultivation of their farms, have a surplus produce for market, invite emigrants, & then we shall be able to pay our state revenue without the sheriff's taking our childrens bread." After such delay the people of Indiana could enter the Union as wise men, but its immediate assumption would result in the tax exemption of all lands sold by the federal government within Indiana for five years from the date of sale; make the salaries of the governor, judges and secretary payable from state rather than federal revenues; and result in additional expense because of more offices. If the territorial government were retained, the expense and the
33
Lexington , Indiana, Cornucopia of the West, June 8, 1816.
34 See Carter, The Territorial Papers of the United States
, VIII, 311–312, 377–379.
35 This was an understatement. Moreover, statehood ended the federal subsidy for salaries and certain other items. This made the increase to Indiana taxpayers relatively much higher. See the closing paragraph of this article for summary concerning expenditures during the first decade of statehood.
ability to pay taxes would gradually become proportionate to that required to support a state establishment and pay revenue to the United States .36 There is much to be said for the validity of "Republican's" thesis, but fiscal policy of a government is not always in accordance with valid theories and practices.

On June 10, 1816, the constitutional convention convened at Corydon and next day voted 34 to 8 to frame a constitution and the preponderance of this majority indicates much popular support for the statehood movement.37 Jonathan Jennings was made chairman of the convention.38 Less than two weeks later the Western Sun quoted from a letter received from Corydon:
The Convention have determined by a majority of 33 to 8, to launch our political vessel of state, and I am afraid without having a sufficient number of skillful navigators on board, at least to manage the vessel in case of a storm.—But with such an overwhelming majority in favor of a state government, the people must take it as a mad [man] takes his wife, "for better or worse," &c. with but this exception, a divorce cannot be obtained.39
Within about three weeks the constitution was framed and during the next few months a state government was organized,40" but. formal admission was delayed until December 11 when President Madison approved a joint-resolution of Congress declaring Indiana a member of the Union.41 The Hoosier state has never been without a sufficient number of would-be navigators, but not all have been of equal skill as pilots of the ship of state!

The average annual cost of state government during the first decade of statehood was approximately twenty-five thousand dollors,42 yet this initial decade was a difficult period
36
Vincennes , Indiana, Western Sun, June 1, 1816, in a supplement to the regular issue.
37 Kettleborough, Constitution Making in Indiana, I, 78–79.
38 Ibid., xvii.
39
Vincennes , Indiana, Western Sun, June 22, 1816.
40 Kettleborough, Constitution Making in Indiana, I, xvii-xxii. For another study of the constitution see Ruth E. Brayton, The Constitution of 1816 (A.M. Thesis, Indiana University, Bloomington , Indiana, 1929); Esarey, History of Indiana, I, 252–254.
41 Annals of Congress, 14 Cong., 2 Sess., 1348; Kettleborough, Constitution Making in Indiana, I, 131–132.
42 Carmony, Indiana Public Finance, 1800–1826, Table IV, between pages 155–156, has a summary of expenditures during the first decade of statehood based on annual reports of the state treasurer.
with much deficit financing involving relatively large issues of state treasury notes.43 By the mid 1820's, however, the depression had lifted, population and resources were larger, the state debt was almost liquidated, and Indiana was entering a decade in which the fiscal skies would generally be dear, and the state would continue to grow in population and resources at an amazing rate. The fiscal objection to statehood seems to have been largely forgotten as Indiana became proud of her place in the Union.

list.item: 43 Ibid., 149–251. For laws authorizing treasury notes Laws of the State of Indiana, 1820–1821, pp. 40–44; ibid., 1821–1822, p. 108–110; ibid, 1822–182.3, pp. 38–40; Special Laws of the State of Indiana, 1813–1824, pp. 91–95, see section 4, pp. 94–95. See also various reports and annual messages of the governors as found in contemporary House and Senate Journals.

div.head: List of Contributors
div.p:
Nadine K. Fichter (Mrs. George S.), is a senior in the School of Education at Miami University,
Oxford, Ohio .
Donald F. Carmony is assistant professor of history at the Indiana University Extension Center, South Bend , Indiana.
T. W. Records is a resident of New Harmony , Indiana.
Frederick Kuhns is a Congregational minister now living at Rochester, New York .
Howard H. Peckman is the director of the Indiana Historical Bureau and secretary of the Indiana Historical Society, Indianapolis , Indiana.
Elfrieda Lang is the secretary and assistant to the editor of the Indiana Magazine of History, Bloomington , Indiana.
John C. Andressohn is associate professor of history at Indiana University, Bloomington , Indiana.
Cedric Cummins is a member of the history department at the University of South Dakota, Vermillion , South Dakota.
Oscar O. Winther is assistant professor of history at Indiana University, Bloomington , Indiana.

div.head: Flatboats
div.p: The Ohio River, a great river flowing majestically between green, wooded hills, is known in story and song as "The Beautiful Ohio ." To those of us who have spent even a part of our lives on the Ohio River, or who live in the great Ohio Valley, the stream has woven a romantic spell which never dies.

Associated with the story of the Ohio River, its discovery in 1760, its development by traders, missionaries, frontiersmen, early settlers, and finally the establishment of towns, cities, and states, is the growth of water transportation, which is interesting and fascinating of itself. As a boy, I listened with wide eyes to stories of Indians in canoes skimming swiftly and silently on the stream which had been taken up by large and noisy steamboats with heavy cargoes of passengers and freight, or of the large war canoes manned by twenty or thirty painted savages making a surprise attack on other tribes. Then, as soon as the white man appeared, the Indians turned their cruel warfare against him, and many tales were told of ambush, fighting, and massacres. The historic Pigeon Roost Massacre had occurred not far away, while the ambush and slaying of Colonel Archibald Laughery and about one hundred officers and men at the mouth of the stream, which now bears his name, was almost in sight of my birthplace, and Laughery Island was less than two miles distant. I was thrilled by accounts of a few men who escaped and who had nerve wracking experiences when Indians searched for them in thickets and hills. One soldier, though severely injured, managed to swim to the Kentucky side where he found a hiding place by squeezing into a crevice of Split Rock where he lay for two or three days while Indians passed within a few yards of him, and he could see their feet and legs when one or two remained absolutely still while the others noisily took their canoes out on the river. They finally gave up and he escaped.

My boyhood was spent on a farm below Rising Sun, Indiana, where my parents moved while I was quite young. I always liked to watch the river and sometimes climbed a large sycamore tree on the riverbank where I spent many pleasant hours watching boats pass or just watching the eddies in
the current and the driftwood as it floated slowly along—seeing in boyish imagination the craft of years long gone, the canoes of bark or of hollowed logs, and the boats of the early settlers and explorers. The white man had first come as explorer and trader, then came settlers. There were no roads at first and the blazed trails were often hard to follow, and much of the time they were impassable, so on this account and also the dangers from wild beasts and savage Indians, the early travelers turned to the Ohio River. One narrator said:
The Ohio River was the more available and the surest means of transportation, the other being Shank's mare and lumbering oxen that drew ponderous wagons down the dimly lit corridors of the teeming wilderness. The adventurous pioneers could not lose their way by river. Their arrival at Cincinnati , and all the numerous other settlements that had begun to dot the verdured shores of the river, was inevitable. Of necessity it was a slow method of transportation, but there was no impetuous hurry on the part of the future settlers to beat the clock, as, mentally, they were resigned and easy-going and deliberate as the current which bore them from the bustling port of Pittsburgh into the empurpled mists of the beckoning Southwest.1

Among the craft employed in 1800 were two contrasting types. One was called the keelboat while the other was named the flatboat. Keelboats varied in size from small ones, five or six feet in width and twenty to thirty feet long and with sharp bow and stern, to large ones up to 120 feet in length. On the small keelboats there was a narrow running board on each side. These were used by the crew to pole their boats upstream when they were unable to cordelle them. It required from six to ten men to force the boat upstream. Half of the crew was on either side of the boat. Each man was given a long pole. "They set their poles at the head of the boat, brought the end of the pole to their shoulder, bent over, and walked on the running boards to the stern. At the captain's order they returned quickly to the head for a new start."2 Such boats, under favorable conditions, made the trip from New Orleans to Cincinnati in sixty to ninety days, bringing cargoes of five or six tons. Larger keelboats were constructed on the order of ocean craft and were built by trained shipbuilders. They were made with a keel the entire
1 Frank Y. Grayson, Thrills of the Historic Ohio River (n.p., n.d.), 17.
2 Ibid., 5.
length of the hull which made them steady and easily steered, and this gave them their name. Such boats were usually from sixty to ninety feet long and a few even larger were built. Though narrow, these boats were quite commodious and could carry much freight as well as a number of passengers, who rode very comfortably. These boats had oars and usually carried removable running boards so that poles could be used if necessary. Poling was slow and required a large crew. These large keelboats were expensive to build, expensive to operate, and by the ordinary citizen regarded as aristocrat, which did not appeal to the hardy frontiersmen.

Most pioneers had very little capital, but possessed ambition, industry and courage. They soon developed a very simple craft which required neither skilled labor nor blue prints to construct. At first log rafts were constructed, sometimes with small cabins to protect the travelers and their household goods from the weather. Occasionally, in all emergency such a craft came apart. They then devised a simple boat with square sides and a flat bottom, and they called it a flatboat. This plain craft with the simple name became the boat cf the common people just as the early Ford car was known much later as the car of the common folks. On small flatboats family groups or several families from the same community came down the Ohio River to settle, clear the land, build homes, and thus set up an inland empire. One such boat is said to have had 105 people aboard, all members of the Anderson family, as told me by a grandson, E. A. Anderson, now almost ninety years of age. He said that two boats came all the way from Pennsylvania and landed at Mt. Vernon , Indiana. The other boat had over seventy persons on it belonging to three families, Matthew, Saultzman, and Wilson. There are many descendants of these families still living in Posey County . The lives of these early settlers doubtless seemed commonplace to them, and few pioneers realized the importance of their efforts. Yet, like the laborers on the temple at Jerusalem, who were commended for their faithfulness and fidelity, so these pioneers were laying the foundation of orderly government all through the Ohio Valley. Their work was vital.

In a short time, land had been cleared and abundant crops raised so that larger markets were needed. Learning that the people in the South raised only two or three crops, such
as cotton and sugar cane, and that they needed staple food crops for their horses and cattle as well as for themselves, the enterprising folks along the Ohio took advantage of the situation and began to build flatboats which were familiar to them. Men with capital to invest had larger boats built and employed reliable and experienced men to take them down the Ohio and Mississippi , usually all the way down to New Orleans where they disposed of their cargoes and then sold the boats.

About the time the flatboating era began to develop another factor also entered the situation. A steamboat came puffing and clanging down the river from Pittsburgh in 1811 where she had been built on the same plans as the "Clermont" which Robert Fulton had built on the Hudson River and which had been widely advertised as a success. The story of the steamboat is quite fascinating in itself. Grayson in his Thrills of the Historic Ohio River has much valuable information about the Ohio River boats of all kinds.

Though the problem of propelling boats by "elastic vapor" had been pretty well solved by Robert Fulton , yet rivermen, especially polers and other crewmen, doubted that steamboats would be of any practical use. They did not believe the steamboat could make the long trip upstream from New Orleans to Pittsburgh . "Steamboat? Humph!" they grunted. "When we see one of the contraptions out there on the river we will believe it! When horses grow six legs then only will we be convinced that a boat can be pushed through the waters by other than man power."3 On the afternoon of October 27, 1811, when the " New Orleans ," as the first steamboat was named, came around the bend above Cincinnati everyone who could do so came to the river to see her. She anchored in midstream and no one could come within several yards of her unless they had special permits. The late P. S. Bush of
Covington, Kentucky , described the excitement which the passage of the " New Orleans " caused.
In the fall of the year 1811, after the embargo was laid on English vessels, and before the earthquakes of December, 1811, my father was residing on the Ohio River nearly opposite Gen. Harrisonk farm at North Bend. The family was much surprised one day by seeing the young Mr. Weldons running down the river bank, much alarmed and shouting, "The British are coming down the river." There had, of
3 Ibid., 19.
course, been a current rumor of war with that power. All the family immediately ran to the bank. We saw something, I knew not what, but supposed it was a sawmill from the working of the lever beam, making its slow but solemn progress with the current. We were shortly afterwards informed that it was a steamboat.4
The flatboat men made many jokes at the expense of the new craft, but they little realized how much difference it would make in their lives and also in the development of the business and economic life all through the valley. As the years passed, the steamboat was improved and flatboats soon became only secondary to them. Since this is the story of flat-boats, we must pass on.

One incident of the keelboat seems worth repeating here as it shows the importance of the Ohio River to the development of other than the material interests of the Midwest. A large, fine keelboat came gaily around the bend above Rising Sun one fine day in December, 1825. This boat landed and several well-dressed men and women came ashore and introduced themselves to the folks who were gathering to see them and their boat. One of them, Robert Dale Owen, explained that his father, Robert Owen, of Scotland , had purchased the community known as Harmonie, Indiana, located about fifty miles up the Wabash River from where it empties into the Ohio . Harmonie had been established in 1814 by a religious group under the leadership of George Rapp who expected to live to see the second coming of Christ. This town, on the banks of the Wabash , had been constructed with unusually substantial and commodious buildings, land had been cleared, large fields put under cultivation, orchards and vineyards set out, and sheep, goats, hogs, and cattle for dairy and beef were raised. Several industries had also been set up. Above all stood the great church in the form of a Maltese cross which had been constructed with unsually fine skill in design and workmanship. The Harmonie Society and community had been organized as a co-operative group with all sharing equally. Since their markets were too far away and too hard to reach, they had sold to Robert Owen and had removed to a place they had selected in Pennsylvania which they named Economy.

Robert Owen had many advanced ideas for all humanity. Robert Dale Owen explained that many of the more than thirty
4 Ibid., 18.
persons aboard the keelboat had formerly been connected with the Philadelphia Academy of Science, and they had prepared to re-establish this institution in the new location which had been renamed New Harmony . Robert Owen and William Maclure, who had joined him, intended to establish free schools including kindergartens, trade schools, and the sciences Among the passengers were Thomas Say, who afterwards became famous as a scientist, and Lucy Sistaire, who later married Say. She was an unusually talented artist and made drawings which she embelished and also paintings of shell fish which Thomas Say collected and classified. Others included two other sons of Robert Owen, Richard Dale Owen and David Dale Owen, and also Joseph Neef and family. When William Maclure first met Neef, he was principal of a large school in Paris . Maclure engaged him to have charge of the schools, and his contract stipulated that he would be granted an annuity upon retirement. On the keelboat were many valuable books, scientific equipment, household goods, and unusual articles, such as a clock with rotating pendulum which was more than one hundred years old at that time. Though the Owen community as planned was not a success, yet the young men and women who went there to organize schools had a great influence on the intellectual development of the Midwest. One of Robert Owen's sons became the first president of Purdue University, and one of the buildings at Indiana University is named Owen Hall in honor of Richard Dale Owen, who was a professor in the university several years. The unusual character of the sons of Robert Owen is shown in an unusual way at the capitol building of Indiana where there are two memorials, each placed there by voluntary contributions of many people. One is a monument on the statehouse grounds, which was placed there by the women of Indiana and the nation to honor Robert Dale Owen for the efforts he had made, and with considerable success, for the rights of women. The other is a large plaque which is in the rotunda of the building and was furnished by the voluntary contributions of former Confederate prisoners of war in Camp Morton of which Colonel Richard Owen was commandant. The inscription reads: "In honor of Col. Richard Dale Owen who was more like a father than a jailor to us."

The work of writing this brief story of the flatboat era was suggested to me by James G. Daly, whose grandfather,
Captain Jim Daly, was a flatboatman practically all his life. When I taught in Rising Sun High School, James Daly was in some of my classes, and we became quite good friends. Unexpectedly, James Daly turned the tables on his former English teacher by assigning me the task of writing an essay about the flatboat period. Captain Jim Daly had made his first trip when Indiana was just a new state and carried on until about the last flatboat was to leave Rising Sun when he became ill. His son came to bring him home on a steamboat, but by some accident Captain Jim fell from the steamboat as they were about to land at home, and he sank from sight—his body was never recovered. He had spent his entire life building flatboats, loading them, and piloting them to New Orleans and other places down the river, then finally, the water of the Ohio River closed over him, and the river became his final resting place.

I was flattered when I was chosen to write the article on flatboats, but when I began to check upon my stock of information on the subject, I realized that it was woefully brief and indefinite. When I began to look for some one to hell) me, I was exceptionally fortunate to find two friends who have done so much that they should have most of the credit for the story as it now appears. One is Mrs. Lucie Rieman. Aurora , Indiana, whose father was a flatboat pilot. She made several trips to New Orleans when she was a child. The other is Mrs. Abby May Espey Warren , Rising Sun, Indiana, whose family had been in the flatboat business for many years. She had seen the activities of building large boats each year and the work and organized hustle and bustle of loading them as quickly as possible in order to get them on their way before the earliest freeze could catch them. These two friends gave the information and with it a personal touch. Mrs. Warren arranged a meeting of her brother, Stewart Espey, and Clarence Bedgood, who had also been actively engaged in the flatboat business in the period following the Civil War. One was eighty-six years old and the other eighty-seven. Espey did not make many trips, — but helped manage the large business until it ceased to be profitable in the late eighties. Bed-good spent many years on smaller coasting boats or on shop-boats. These two old-timers recalled that when they were small boys they became involved in a fight. Mrs. Bloss, who had an ice cream parlor was just bringing the brine from
freezing a batch of cream and was about to empty it into the gutter, but when she saw the fight she threw the brine on them. Hostilities ceased immediately, and they never had another fight. We are very fortunate indeed to have the story directly from these two veterans as well as from others who were actually in the business.

The first flatboats were not very large, many of them not much larger than houseboats, but as opportunities opened and larger boats were needed the same plan was used and the proportions were about the same. In the first years of the steamboat, there was considerable rivalry between the different crews but as the years passed and steamboats were improved flatboat men often had a steamboat tow their boat back home loaded with goods to be sold in the home stores. Empty flatboats, however, usually sold readily just for the lumber in them because lumber was scarce in the South at that time and those flatboats were made of fine northern timber, oak, yellow poplar, and other kinds. And so there was a steady stream of flatboats passing down the Ohio each fall and out into the Mississippi . Since very few were brought back, new ones had to be built each year.

When James Daly wrote to me concerning the article I was to prepare, he gave me considerable information about the flatboat. Though younger than myself, Daly had seen many flatboats, and once his father moved his family 250 miles down the river from Rising Sun to Alton, Indiana, on a flatboat loaded to go down the Mississippi . James, though only a boy, had helped run this boat so there was Captain Jim Daly, his son Garret, and his grandson James on the same flatboat crew. James G. Daly wrote:
The Flat Boat was distinctly a development of the early pioneers. It was square at both ends and absolutely flatbottomed. The two ends rounded up, as you will remember, and the bottom was nailed on crosswise and there was nothing on the bottom at all to keep it from going in any direction that it pleased. It had oars on the sides that were managed from the roof and were called "sweeps" and they had one oar on each end—on the rear end they called it the steering oar and on the other end the gouger. That was used to throw the boat in any direction they wanted to go when they had to make a sudden change. It took a lot of strength to manage a gouger, because the boat was drifting down on to that oar and when they dipped into the water to take a bite of it they just had to fairly lift the boat sidewise from the end. They needed this in order to avoid snags, trees and stumps and all the other things that you tell about in your story.
These boats were small in the beginning, of course, but they grew into very great boats. Some of them that left the landing in Ohio from Rising Sun were 24 and 30 feet wide and 100 to 120 feet long and it took real power to run them. There would be two sweeps on each side of them with three men to a sweep and two men on the gouger and one on the steering oar. They cut a piece of a tree and brought it up from the very bottom of the boat clear to the top for a check post about which they would let the roap slide when they wanted to slow the boat down and they had one of them at each end. They had platforms across the boat to manage the steering oar and the gouger and other platforms along the sides to manage the sweeps, with the men walking on the left side of the boat to manage the sweep on the right side, because it was long and balanced and had to have a lot of room to operate. With the aid of these oars they could take the boat almost any place they pleased. They also always had a mast erected on them with a sail that they could use when the weather was windy enough to carry the boat along, but not windy enough to make it unmanageable. These boats were built up with heavy planks on the sides to a height of about five feet and from that mark on up they were built of ordinary ship lap siding until they were about eight feet on the sides and perhaps ten feet in the middle with a ridge pole and stanchion that went down through there and then they took green lumber and laid the boards crosswise and nailed them on the sides and nailed them off straight and then covered that with tarred paper and laid another row of boards, lapping the joints so it would not leak. In the rear end they built a "fan-tail" which was nothing more than a sort of platform out there on which the house of convenience was located and the cabin or the place where the men slept and ate was just inside of that They had a stove in there and a table and a kitchen and bunks along the wall and that gave an entry out to the boat proper where the cargo was stored and another one to the rear of the boat to the steps that came up onto the top when the cry of "Oars" came from the pilot.
These were the boats that made the history of the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers and that carried the provisions for all of the people that went down that river and lived along those rivers in the early days. My grandfather made his first trip in 1818 as a cabin boy and he lived on that river until 1902—a long, long time as you can see.5

The hull was the most important part of the flatboat and required good material and workmanship. There was plenty of excellent timber near by, but much of the heavy lumber came from Cincinnati because small sawmills could not turn out the lumber fast enough, especially the boards twenty to thirty feet long. The heavy boards were fastened by large nails or spikes and all seams were calked and sometimes hot tar was run into them, but not always. Calking which the
5 James G. Daly, Columbus, Ohio , to T. W. Records, New Harmony , Indiana, May 10, 1944.
men pronounced "corkin" made a lot of noise, especially when several men were working at the same time. Even when carefully calked, the hulls would leak some. In order to protect the cargo as well as to protect the bottom from being knocked loose by the cargo, a floor was laid a few inches above the bottom. To take care of the leakage, hand pumps were put in. These as well as the entire construction of the flatboat, were very simple. They had wooden tubes about four inches square and all valves were of wood and leather. To make the job of pumping easier spring poles were placed to pull the piston stem up, so about all the men had to do was to push down as it almost raised itself.

Mrs. Lucie Ricmam wrote:
My father [William Kirtley Baker] was a Pilot for 30 years. In September, 1883, I was permitted to go to New Orleans with my mother and father on his boat—like all "old flatboaters" I would like to make the trip again. At that time I was ten years old, yet the memories of that trip and other very pleasant trips still remain vividly with me. But now few remain of the men who owned and operated flatboats. On my first trip, besides my father, there were seven men who all became successful business men in Aurora . They were Langtree, McGuire, William Mabin, Andy Winkley, Edson Winkley, Hy Cox, and my Uncle George Mitchell . Some others from Aurora were Abram Hill, grandfather of Edwin C. Hill, Jacob Harbaugh, Asa Hubbard, and Aaron Huffman. It was considered quite the thing, in a cultural way, to take the trip to New Orleans . The last trips from Aurora were made in 1893 when flatboating ceased to be a profitable business. The flatboat was like a barge with sides built up and roofed, with two oars on each side and one at each end. These oars were used to keep it in the channel because if it grounded there was no way to get it afloat again. Not many boats were built at Aurora but were built above here, probably at Cincinnati , but they were brought here to be finished, equipped, and loaded. A cabin, also used as a kitchen, was built at the bow of the boat and another at the stern for bunks. There was a slightly elevated bottom as all flatboats leaked more or less, but hand pumps took care of that. A spar at each end of the boat was used to keep it away from the bank, but I might add, if there was a heavy wind the squeaking of those spars were not music, especially if you wanted to sleep. Now as to our cargo; we went 8 or 10 miles down to Rising Sun, passing Laughery Creek, Split Rock, and the home of your grandfather, Captain Tom Pate, who lived in a large brick house opposite the head of Laughery Island. Farther down we rounded a bend and came to Rising Sun. Here we stopped and took on many barrels of apples and potatoes. We then went on, stopping at other places to take on hay, corn, flour, meal, dried fruits and various other things which my father knew he could sell at a profit. At some larger
places he laid in supplies of such things as green coffee, navy beans and staple groceries — which had a market along the coast, as the Mississippi below Memphis was called. Though a medium sized boat and loaded to go on to New Orleans yet we stopped at a number of places and sold our miscellaneous supplies, especially where coasting boats had landed for years. At these points, below Memphis , many white folks patronized us but there were more colored people who bought our goods. It was slow traveling and a rather lazy life and a happier group of men would be hard to find. The scenery along the Ohio and Mississippi rivers is very beautiful. At Rockport we bought two well built skiffs which were a great convenience to us and when we got to New Orleans we sold them for more than they had cost. When we wanted to land or any of the men went ashore they used these skiffs. To land they took the large rope to shore and fastened it to a tree or other solid object and then, by means of the check post, would land our boat. Our last landing to take on cargo was at Cairo, Illinois , where they shot bales of hay and sacks of oats down a long chute to the deck—it was quite exciting to me to see this. The boats left Aurora about the middle of September each year so they could get to the Mississippi before ice began to form, but it got us at Cairo one trip and the men took pike poles and pushed the larger cakes away to keep them from making holes in the hull. On one trip our boat sprung a leak while we were passing through the locks at Louisville so we had to stop right there to take care of it. The men who operated the locks were irritated and mother was worried but she took the rag carpet up from the cabin floor for calking and saved the day. The lock keeper.; did not use very nice language and father was pretty sore, as it was not his fault; but it soon became just another anecdote of the flatboating business. When we neared New Orleans the little sail boats with dagoes selling oranges and bananas or oysters and shrimp were a welcome sight because I was tired of eating pies made of dried apples, dried prunes, or dried peaches. When we landed at New Orleans a tug boat towed us to the landing right beside an ocean going vessel. When we disposed of our cargo and sold our boat we attended the wonderful Cotton Exposition. To me, however, about all I recall seeing were the Liberty bell and Peter Cooper's first steam engine. Returning by train I got a real thrill crossing Lake Ponchatrain on a long trestle and for a time we were out of sight of land. But when we reached Cincinnati in February, 1883, we found the Ohio River having the greatest flood of its history, and which, for many years, we supposed to be the all time high water. Hut in 1937 we were sadly disillusioned when the 1884 flood was topped by several feet; so now we wonder if the all time high has finally been reached. Rut modern flood control measures will be carried nut before many years, I am sure. The following fall we went again and at that time I saw the Mardi Gras which so impressed me that I am thrilled at the memory of that gorgeous parade. In closing I want to say that my father made several trips to Louisville and had his boat towed back. The Wymonds had a large cooper shop in Aurora and then established one
in Louisville and father took cargoes of hoop poles and other material down.6

Mrs. May Espey Warren of Rising Sun, Indiana, related the following about flatboats and of a flatboat trip she took:
Flatboats varied in size from smaller boats in coast trade and which were ten feet wide by fifty feet long to produce boats made for the trip direct to New Orleans , or for trade along the Mississippi . These were as much as 25 feet wide by 125 feet long. The material used was oak and yellow poplar. The boats were all built locally though the heavier bottom planks were usually obtained from Cincinnati and constructed by local boat builders, who became quite expert. For many years twenty to thirty flatboats left Rising Sun each year. The flatboat business extended all along the Ohio River — Ohio , Indiana, and Illinois on the north side and West Virginia and Kentucky on the south side. The larger boats always carried a recognized pilot. On early boats the pilot guided by trees, local land marks, hills and the like, as there were no government lights then. Also there were many obstructions which were later removed by the government. Many of the smaller boats were built in large creeks and loaded by farmers in the vicinity as a co-operative enterprise, which may have helped spread the idea of farm co-operatives as we now have them. And some of the farm boys who raised the crops also helped build the flatboats and later made the trip down the river. One such place was Hartford , on Laughery Creek, which boasted a "ship yard" for many years. This traffic by farmers was largely before the Civil War. My father commenced flatboating when about twenty years of age. Afterwards, for many years, he loaded and sent flatboats each year but did not himself make the trips. However I remember when I was a little child my father had two flatboats that were caught in early river ice. They were saved but the danger made all the crew leave with the exception of one man. This man saved a heavy loss because flatboats which had been abandoned could be siezed and claimed by law. It seems strange there were so few flatboats lost for the hazards were great and there was a rather heavy investment. Material alone in a large boat would cost at least $750, and the labor, though cheap, ran the cost up. The cargo, sometimes as much as 2,500 barrels of potatoes which cost when loaded, from $3,000 to $5,000. The boats were usually sold to be wrecked after the cargoes were disposed of, but occasionally one was brought back by tow boat. It seems strange that boat after boat was loaded with potatoes, here, while now not enough potatoes are raised for local needs. 1 remember well the long lines of potato wagons coming into Rising Sun to be weighed and loaded on flat-boats at the landing, in the fall, ready to start as early as possible. In those years the Espeys probably sent more flatboats than any other family in Rising Sun. Those were both through boats, loaded
6 Mrs. Lucie B. Rieman, Aurora , Indiana, to Thos. W. Records, New Harmony , Indiana, September 9, 1944, and September 24, 1944.
with potatoes or corn and hay and usually consigned to New Orleans , or produce boats loaded with things to be sold along the Mississippi below Memphis , and usually referred to as "the coast." Several large flatboats were sent each year by various Rising Sun men operating them, and besides these cargoes a vast amount of produce went south on steam boats which was sent by some of the same men. Those active in the flatboat business then were Captain Jim Daly, H. S. Espey, H. Espey, Walker and Bedgood, Ullery, Ben C. Calkins, George McAroy, Oscar Jones, Samuel R. Seward, Ed Granger, Captain William Hemphill, Pierce & Jackson (a blacksmith boat, afterward Pierce & Steel), James Hastings, Grace, J. W. Talbot, Jeff Howard, Captain Ben North, John Clore, Ruben Clore, Captain John C. Miller and probably many others. Your grandfather, Captain Tom Pate, had some thrilling flatboat experiences with which you are probably familiar. Often over 100 flatboat men would return on the same steamboat, their flatboat trip completed about the same time. In this way the two somewhat rival groups, steam boat men and flatboat men, came to know each other and got along fine. Sometimes a flatboat going south would meet a packet with a large white "0" between its smoke stacks, indicating she was of the Ohio River line. The crew would send out a skiff and the men would call, "T-h-r-o-w u-s a p-a-p-e-r." Usually the steam boats carried bundles of late papers which they distributed along the way at landings and these were read over and over by a crew floating along toward market. On one trip Henry and Ruben Clore, who were manufacturing plows and other farm equipment, adapted to use in raising cotton and other southern crops, loaded two boats which they chained together. Just above Memphis they struck an obstruction and both boats were lost—not having any insurance. This loss of several thousand dollars practically ruined these fine men, financially. Another boat owned by the Espeys and operated by Frank Espey, then a young man, went aground near New Madrid, Missouri . They threw barrel after barrel overboard to lighten it but an unusually early freeze caught them and they were held up for six weeks. Coasting boats would take up business wherever they could, and besides selling at southern plantations they landed at small towns and sometimes did a very good business. But the local merchants did not like the outside competition so licenses with pretty high fees were required of flatboats. Then some of the boats that had been accustomed to stopping there would tie up on the opposite side of the river and customers came across in skiffs, but sometimes the crew loaded their skiff and took it across near the town and sold the contents, sometimes as much as $100 worth in a single skiff load. On a trip in 1876 the Bedgoods found Memphis with a rare blanket of 22 inches of snow and with such heavy ice that the steamer "H. P. Schenck," with Dick Burns, of Rising Sun, as clerk, had to have a tug boat move her. At first all flatboats were loaded along the Ohio River and went out into the Mississippi to the South. This did not change until the Illinois Central railway began to bring produce to Cairo which was loaded on the boats from large warehouses along the high levee; then many boats would count on
completing their loads at Cairo, and it is said that as many as 20 or 30 flatboats would be loading or waiting their turns at the same time, while in addition sometimes a half dozen packets for lower Mississippi, St. Louis , or up the Missouri River were there, too. Since flatboats floated always down stream they could not carry material and supplies to the pioneers in the great West, but steam boats did that work. The flatboat era was at its height just before the Civil War and revived for a period after the war but finally ended in the 1890's.
When I was sixteen years old, my parents decided to make a flat-boat trip, and in April I joined them at Natchez, Mississippi . My trip to Natchez was made on the steam boat " Houston " which was a large, beautiful boat with Captain Lew Kates in charge. Through years I have traveled much but I can recall no trip as pleasant as that one. The scenery was beautiful all the way down especially the native verdure on the Ohio . The passengers were treated as guests, officers took us on tours through cities and towns where we landed enroute. At Natchetz I met my parents and transferred to the flatboat.
