The load was practically sold out so we coasted slowly along from Natchez to New Orleans . This gave me an opportunity to see the mansions of ante-bellum days, and how stately those white pillared homes looked; a perfect setting for all the romantic southern stories of school girl days. I recall glorious moonlight nights, the flatboat moving silently down stream, the singing of negroes in cabins or in churches, wafted from shore. Occasionally a big steamer passed, fruit luggers glided by. We were anxious to finish the trip and reach New Orleans and the broad, beautifully moonlit river gave good opportunity to continue often until past midnight, before tying up for the night. The levees were lower then giving us a good view of the shores. The former Baton Rouge state house must have been an architect's night mare, but with its turrets and towers, my young mind pictured it just like English castles and very beautiful. The entire trip from Natchez to New Orleans seemed indescribably lovely. That section was called the sugar coast. Finally our weather worn flatboat tied up in the busiest harbor I have ever seen, New Orleans . It was overwhelming to a little girl from Rising Sun to see many ocean going vessels, steam boats galore, gulf boats of all kinds and a vast amount of freight being loaded and unloaded on the open levees—hundreds of negroes running back and forth, the mates yelling and swearing at the negroes constantly.
I have wished that I might have helped you more, but my first hand knowledge of flatboating was just the afterglow of a factor that had been vital in our family and our town for a long time. How eagerly I listened each year for the throaty whistle of steam boats which meant the return of family members who had taken a flatboat "down the river." And we were sure that in addition to a returning brother there would be a bunch of bananas—a luxury in that day. Too, I enjoyed the annual September exploration of flatboats, the loading, and the smell of new lumber. So you see I had a bit of flatboating. And long afterward, at a New York art exhibition, I
found a picture of a flatboat painted by an early American artist. I wonder if any others who viewed that painting had ever heard of a flatboat7

Relations between Northern flatboat men and Southern, white people became strained just before the Civil War, but after the war hostility declined somewhat, though it still persisted. An incident involved Steven Dibble, of Patrior, when he was having a tugboat take his flatboat in at New Orleans . Steve was wearing his old army overcoat with several buttons missing. There was a strong wind and Dibble probably did not trust the ex-Confederate tugboat skipper so he dashed from side to side and from one end to the other with his coat flapping in the wind. A spectator said, "lookit the damned Yank, flyin’ round like he had hot grease in his pants."

References have been made to my grandfather, Captain Thomas Pate, so I feel that I should not omit telling something about him, but am sorry to say that I do not have much relating to his experiences as a flatboat man. He got his earliest experience on one of the flatboats built and loaded at Hartford , on Laughery. He made his first trip when he was 18 or 19 years of age and from knowledge of the rivers gained that way, he was able to qualify as a steamboat pilot. During the Civil War, he was a pilot in the navy and served on gunboats operating on the Mississippi River and was on such assignment during the seige of Vicksburg. It happened that he was the only pilot on board when the final engagement started so he had to stand at the wheel for 36 hours without relief. Half of the pilot wheel was torn off by a point blank cannon ball which he escaped by dropping to the floor as he saw the gunner touch his match to the vent. Captain Pate became part owner and captain of a steamboat after the Civil War. One narrow escape he had was before the war when he was pilot on the steamer "Red Stone" which blew up while he was at the wheel. Though severely injured, he managed to get hold of some wreckage and kept afloat until rescued. But such incidents belong in the story of steamboats. Captain Tom, as his friends called him, once had an unusual experience when he took a flatboat south before the war. It was customary, if the Southern planter made the necessary arrangements, for his people to get such supplies as he authorized, and he would settle for them
7 Mrs. Abby May Warren , Rising Sun, Indiana, to T. W. Records, New Harmony , Indiana, July 20, 1944, and October 12, 1944.
when the boat was ready to leave. At one such plantation Captain Tom found that this planter had sometimes failed to pay up. He also learned that he kept a pack of savage-blood hounds at the mansion house. After sending word that he was ready to leave and getting no response, he made the long trip to the mansion house. It was surrounded by a high board fence with a small gate as an entrance. He went through the gate, but was no sooner inside when the savage dogs rushed out from under the "gallery." He could have escaped by jumping back through the gate, but he quickly decided differently. He ran to a corner so no dog could reach him except from the front. The first one rushed at him, but Captain Tom was wearing very heavy boots and placed a kick which gave the hound a major stomach-ache, another one came flying at him and went down with stomach trouble also. The rest of the pack hesitated, and the owner emerged from the house and whistled for his hounds—two of them did not come. The planter began accusing grandfather of killing his best hounds, but he was told he owed a certain sum and that it was due immediately. He paid and grandfather left with his revolver in sight and was soon on his boat and on his way. A similar incident did not come out so well. In that case the flatboat captain went to collect but did not return. His crew went 011 a search and found the captain's body—he had been murdered and robbed. After one of his earliest trips, Tom Pate came back to his home near Hartford unannounced. He arrived soon after dark and a light snow was falling, through a window of the shoeshop he saw several friends so he took off his shoes and then gave a shrill whistle and ran out of sight on his toes. When they rushed out and saw his tracks, they decided it was a "painter" which was their name for a wildcat, but just as they were organizing to hunt for it, Tom Pate walked out and repeated his whistle. Thus Captain Tom lived near the river and on the river until he and his wife left the old brick house near Laugliery Island which had been his home so long and which he could see from the deck of his steamers as he passed. He retired to Rising Sun and afterward he and his son, T. Smith Pate, loaded a coasting boat. One evening my father took us to see this boat which was tied up at Rabbit Hash, Kentucky . We crossed from Rising Sun and after we had visited awhile in the cabin of my uncle Smith said he had to see if the boat was leaking and asked if I would like to go along. The hull was pitch dark and the lantern made weird shadows
which looked awfully scary to a four-year old boy, but Uncle Smith kept talking as if to himself until suddenly he acted quite surprised to find some candy which it seemed he did not know was there. He got a nice bag of striped stick candy which he gave to me and when we got back to the cabin, he produced another bag for the other guests so I didn't have to share my candy after all. And thus I can say I did have some flatboat experience on the last boat that Captain Tom Pate, my grandfather, was interested in. Grandfather had several brothers who made one or more trips from Hartford down the Ohio and Mississippi , and Taylor Pate sent a good many boats from Patriot some of them having been built at Rising Sun. Other Pates were James, Ben, Fletcher, and Peter, though the last named did not do much flatboating.

The story of flatboating is a good deal like the boats themselves, each one was usually a private enterprise and though incidents and experiences were similar yet they did not lend themselves to continuity. In the very early days, there were always snags and sand bars, and for many the falls at Louisville made flatboating rather hazardous. And sometimes gangs would come to a lone boat tied up for the night and would rob crew and boat, but such attacks were infrequent. Shortly after the close of the War of 1812, a gang of murderers and robbers established themselves at Cave in Rock, Illinois . The leader had been an officer in the army. He went under several names, but his real name was Wilson. There is a large cave in the cliff by the river and from this the place gets its name. The gang used this cave which was convenient for them as it had two entrances, one at the foot of a one hundred foot cliff facing the river but hidden by bushes, the other at a level spot on top of the cliff. They had. a hotel back of the cliff which they used to lure travelers. Those who possessed money or other valuables were murdered and robbed. They also waylaid travelers in the wilderness so that it was not safe to travel in that part of Illinois or adjacent Kentucky . As the number of flatboats increased, they turned their attention to them and lured them ashore in different ways. Sometimes a, man would row out by himself and ask for help for his sick family. Other schemes were used, but the results were the same and all the victims were murdered. It is said they even captured one of the early steamboats, but this has never been confirmed. One boat, however, was lost in that vicinity with no survivors. Finally, the government offered a reward of five thousand dollars for
Wilson dead or alive. Five daring men started to win that prize, but they were captured instead. They made Wilson believe they really wanted to join the gang so they were not put to death. As soon as they could, they escaped and realizing the gang was too strong for them to hope for success themselves, they organized a large posse and captured Wilson. Since they were of the opinion that he would try to escape and that his gang would probably try to rescue him, the posse had a brief trial and then executed him. They packed his head in clay and shipped it to Pittsburgh where the outlaw was identified, and the reward sent. That ended the Cave in Rock robber gang. Of course, there were always cases of men disappearing and foul play was suspected, but nothing on such an organized scale.

In the history of flatboating the heaviest single loss from Rising Sun was that of the two Clore boats which were loaded with machinery and repair parts. Later, another flatboat owned, loaded, and manned by Ulmanseik and Stegemiller and named "The Sauer Kraut" struck an unseen object, and flatboat as well as the cargo were a total loss.

Some incidents recorded by historians might have been Rising Sun boats and were, no doubt, known to many Rising Sun inhabitants. One was at Tobinsport, Kentucky , when heavy fog almost caused a collision between a flatboat and a small ferryboat. The pilot said, "I thought sure we would hit that ferry but a tall young fellow who was running it, jumped to the gouger and fairly lifted his boat out of our way. I heard another fellow call him Abe and told him to look out, but Abe had seen us as soon as the other fellow," Then at a later period some of the men related their experiences to the folks back home. They told of the New Orleans slave market and how horrified they had been at some of the things they had seen there. One man said, "I saw a big tall fellow who just stood silent while a half white girl was put up for sale, I saw his knuckles become white as he clenched his fists. Then as he turned away he looked almost sick and he said, "if ever I get a chance I will hit that business and hit it hard"; one of the men with him said he was Abe Lincoln from up Sangamon River in Illinois ." And thus flatboat men gathered ideas and passed them on to friends back home.

One source of information for this article has been, "Happenings of the Past," in the Rising Sun Recorder. There have been several items about flatboats. One which I followed
was about a boat from North's Landing and the crew was listed as Captain J. H. Barker, mate, George North, clerk, Grant North, and chamber maid, Neall Powell. She was reported as loaded with 4,022 barrels of potatoes.8 My home was in sight of North's Landing and I knew all of the crew except Captain Barker so I wrote to Grant North who answered promptly. North said the boat was really a barge with a roof and was not difficult to operate, but was in a tow with nearly a dozen other produce boats of the same kind. Grant continued, "So we had no use for mate, clerk, or chamber maid or cook—about all we did was to eat and sleep going down." It appears, therefore, that the crew just went along for the ride, which was not a bad idea. An item of 1884 said, "H. S. Espey and Son have contracted with W. H. Whitlock for a new flatboat 92 1/2 feet long and 22 1/2 feet wide for the fall trade."9 Another item dated 1874 said that Captain Espey had started south to look after his interests in that direction and that T. Smith Pate was taking Captain Espey's place behind the counter during his absence.10 I can imagine with what keen interest Captain Espey would watch for his own boats floating along, and perhaps, as he passed them, he gave them a brief message from Rising Sun. Then in New Orlems, he would meet commission men and then probably select goods to be sent up to Rising Sun. I recall how quickly the news spread that an Espey flatboat loaded with goods for his stores had been towed up from New Orleans . People flocked to the Espey stores to see even if they did not want to buy. There were groceries of all kinds and also drygoods and other things, many of which were imported or had come down the Atlantic coast and through the Gulf of Mexico. Espey not only stocked his own stores, but permitted other merchants to have some of the goods. It is told that flatboats, in passing, would often hail each other and call out, "Where from and what's your load?" When the answer was "Indiana" they would often laugh and say, "hoop poles and punkins, of course." Crews from boats to the lower Mississippi usually came home on packets or towboats, sometimes working to defray the expense of the trip back. When the boats went no farther than Memphis , especially if navigation was closed by ice, the men sometimes walked home through Tennessee and Kentucky . It is related that three Indiana boys
8 Rising Sun, Indiana, Recorder, December 21, 1944.
9 Ibid., September 7, 1944.
10 Ibid., February 10, 1944.
were coming home on foot, and about dark they came to an old school building and found the door unlocked. They entered and discovered a fire in the stove and a tramp. He would not talk to them, but began scratching himself vigorously which was probably to indicate that there were insects around. The Hoosiers went him one better. They joked about lice and other insects they had met, and then one of them began laughing and when questioned, he said, he had failed to tell them that he had been told that the bed they had slept in the night before had been occupied by a man who had died of smallpox. The tramp left in a hurry. Such incidents, true or not, were the tales told by returning crewmen.
After this article on Flatboats had been completed, I found the following paragraph in the program of the dedication of Human Field at Terre Haute , Indiana, on October 3, 1944.

quote.p: Three methods of transportation peculiar to the early days were outstanding in the Wabash Valley. These were flatboats, river steam boats and canals. The flatboats covered the down-river trade to New Orleans , furnishing to the planters of the South, pork, bacon, lard, beef, cheese, butter, flour, corn, hay, tobacco and whiskey, and were a combination of log cabins, floating barnyard, country grocery and fort, the latter for protection from the river pirates who infested the banks of the lower Ohio and Mississippi . These boats were long and narrow, sixty or more feet in length, and from ten to twenty feet in width. They required from thirty to sixty days to make the trip from this section to New Orleans , and ninety days to return. After 1820 the flatboat crew could return by steamboat. So vast was this transportation system that in the spring of 1826 one hundred and fifty-two of these flatboats passed Vincennes , enroute to New Orleans , coming principally from Terre Haute .

div.p: Thus we see how important the flatboat era was along the entire Ohio River and its tributaries. Boats from as far up the Wabash as Peru came out into the Ohio River below Evansville and then out into the broad Mississippi where men from many places exchanged ideas and laid the foundations for the great empire of the Midwest.

The time came when the Southern markets were closed because of changed transportation and farming methods and even the lumber in the boats was no longer in demand because a great lumber industry had developed in the South. The last flatboat was cast off at Rising Sun with Captain Jim Daly in charge. It drifted slowly down the Ohio River and around East Bend. Those who watched it go out of sight turned to other interests, little did they realize that an era in the history of the Ohio Valley had come to an end—the flatboat era.

div.head: A Sketch of Congregationalism in Indiana to 1858
div.p: The story of early Congregationalism in Indiana has never been fully told. Brief accounts of a general nature, and anniversary sketches of individual churches have, of course, been written, but no adequate treatment of the subject, based on the available manuscript material, has ever appeared. In part this is because Congregationalists were not writing the history of their denomination as leaders of other denominations in Indiana were doing; in part because the source material has not been examined. Still another consideration is that Congregational churches in Indiana were so few in number. This paper is not a complete account of the growth of Congregationalism. It is a sketch, rather than a compendium, of this growth to the year 1858. Its aim is to suggest lines for further treatment, not exhaustively to deal with the subject.

The paucity of early Congregational churches in Indiana poses an interesting problem.2 Speaking generally, Congregational churches were organized by emigrants from the New England states. Although New Englanders settled in Indiana, they were but few in number, as Lois Kimball Mathews has shown.3 Because that element formed a lower percentage of Indiana's population, there is less reason to look for Congregational churches in that state.4

list.item: 1 The writer is preparing a doctoral dissertation at the University of Chicago on the subject, The Operations of the American Home Missionary Society in the Old Northwest, 1826–1861. The material here published is based on that research.

2 The late Secretary of the Indiana Historical Society, Christopher B. Coleman, has stated that one must look to "the religious antecedents of the settlers rather than other considerations" for the weakness of this denomination. Coleman, "Some Religious Developments in Indiana," Indiana Magazine of History ( Bloomington , Indiana, 1905-), V (1909), 63; Outline of Church History of Indiana, Bulletin No. 5 of the Indiana Historical Commission [ Indianapolis , Indiana, 1916], 5.

3 Lois K. Mathews, The Expansion of New England
( Boston , 1909), 196–220.

4 According to the 1850 census the population of Indiana was 988, 416. Yet in comparison with the population which was native to Indiana (541,079), New Englanders numbered only 10,646, or two per cent. Again, in comparison with the number of Indiana settlers who had been born outside of the state but within the United States (390,313), the New England element in Indiana amounted to only 2.7 per cent. In contrast to the situation obtaining in 1850 in Ohio, Michigan, Illinois , and Wisconsin where New Englanders were exceedingly numerous, this element hardly exceeded one per cent of the total

div.p: Aside from the rather general fact that New Englanders were scarce in Indiana, there were no important Congregational colonies in the state; nor had extensive sales of public lands been made to such companies as were purchasing them for New Englanders settling in Michigan and Illinois , thus brightening the prospects of Congregationalism there. Nor, as far as is known, were any Congregational churches constituted at the East for emigration to a preselected site in Indiana. Moreover, it frequently happened that the New Englanders who settled in Indiana were of the Baptist faith, as the settlement of the northern tier of counties illustrates.5

Why did New Englanders not come in larger numbers to Indiana? First, the early settlement of the state had proceeded from the South.6 Emigrants continued to flow from this section to Indiana long after 1825.7 Prior to that date, New Englanders usually reached this part of the West by crossing Ohio or by descending the Ohio River.8 Although Indiana was "free" under the Ordinance of 1787, the threat of slavery was not dealt a death blow in the state until 1823. Emigrants from New England probably did not desire to mingle their strong antislavery prejudices with Southerners. The same argument would apply to Illinois , although some New Englanders took up military lands in that state. It may also be observed that the main current of emigration
population of the state of Indiana. Indiana's foreign-born population (54,426) amounted to more than five times the number of New England emigrants. If, for the purpose of calculation, one adds all who had settled in Indiana by 1850 from the state of New York (24,310), on the theory that a large percentage of these emigrants had originally been New Englanders or were descendants of New Englanders (which is not highly improbable), only 3.5 per cent of the population would have given Indiana a Yankee flavoring. Seventh Census of the United States , 1850, Statistics, xxxvi, 756, 780–781. Since the figures on page 780 vary slightly from those on page xxxvi, those on the latter page were used. The 1860 census showed 12,307 New Englanders in Indiana, or only nine-tenths of one per cent of the total population (1,350,428). Eighth Census of the United States , 1860, Statistics of Population, I, iv, 130.
5 Mathews, The Expansion of New England
, 196–220; History of Steuben County, Indiana ( Chicago , 1885), 455–456.
6 Frederick J. Turner, Rise of the New West (American Nation Series, 28 vols., New York , 1904–1925, edited by Albert B. Hart), XIV (1906), 75–78.
7 John D. Barnhart, "Sources of Southern Migration into the Old Northwest,"
Mississippi Valley Historical Review (Cedar Rapids, Iowa , 1914-), XXII (1935), 49–62.
8 Frederic L. Paxson, "The Gateways of the Old Northwest," Historical Collections … Michigan Pioneer and Historical Society (Lansing, Michigan , 1877–1929), XXXVIII (1912), 139–148.
from New England to the region west of Ohio did not set in until after 1830.9 Second, while the opening of the Erie Canal in 1825 augured well for the settlement of northern Indiana, the results were disappointingly small. Despite the use of the old Detroit - Chicago Trail and the portage of the St. Joseph River at South Bend , it was more difficult to reach Indiana than the Territory of Michigan . Milwaukee and Chicago were more accessible than was the northern tier of Indiana. While southern and eastern Michigan filled rapidly owing to the facility of passage through the Erie Canal, northern Illinois and southern Wisconsin did not share extensively in the migrations from New England until the Winnebago and Black Hawk Indian uprisings had been put down. Even in the 1840's northern Indiana was relatively isolated. As late as 1846 Indiana-bound shipping was considered a bad risk due to storms on Lake Michigan . Damage was repeatedly inflicted by wind and waves on the Michigan City harbor, a harbor whose improvement Congress entirely neglected while the war with Mexico was being prosecuted.10 Third, it has beer, demonstrated that the "wet lands" of the Hoosier state greatly retarded the settlement of its northern and north-central sections.11 Speculation in the public lands of
Illinois, Michigan , and Wisconsin , added to the relative ease with which these regions could be reached by hundreds of thousands of colonists, accounted for a more rapid settlement around and beyond Indiana. Previous to the Panic of 1837, emigrants from the New England states, by-passing Indiana, were pouring into these other states and territories. After 1843 a measure of economic improvement was noticeable and colonists swarmed into them in even greater numbers.12

list.item: 9 Arthur C. Boggess, The Settlement of Illinois , 1778–1830, in Chicago Historical Society, Collections, V ( Chicago , 1908), 146, 180, 185. The defeat of the proslavery forces in Indiana influenced the vote in Illinois in 1824 when the proposal to hold a state convention was decisively beaten.

10 The letters of Erastus Colton, pastor of the Congregational church of Michigan City, Indiana, describe this situation in the later 1840's. Erastus Colton, Michigan City, Indiana, to Milton Badger, New York , December 9, 1847 and April 1, 1848, in the American Home Missionary Society Papers, Hammond Library, Chicago Theological Seminary, Chicago, Illinois .

11 Richard L. Power, "Wet Lands and the Hoosier Stereotype,"
Mississippi Valley Historical Review, XXII, 33–48.

12 Mathews, The Expansion of New England
, 196–249. See also James Thomson, Wabash , Indiana, to Milton Badger, New York , July 1, 1845, who says: "I have been disappointed thus far in the aid that I

div.p: There is a more cogent reason why the forces of Congregationalism in Indiana were impoverished in the early period. This is to be found in the record of the agencies which planted the numerous mission churches, namely, the Presbyterian General Assembly's Board of Missions, the Missionary Society of Connecticut and the United Domestic Missionary Society. In Indiana the appointees of all these agencies organized only Presbyterian churches. Despite the fact that a large percentage of the ministers employed by the two last-named societies were Congregationalists, no Congregational churches were formed in Indiana.13 When the American Home Missionary Society entered the Indiana field in 1826, its appointees followed the precedent of founding Presbyterian churches.14

As far as is known, there was not a Congregational church in Indiana until 1833 when one was formed at Bath , in Franklin County , only a few miles across the state line from Oxford, Ohio , where Robert Hamilton Bishop and his followers in Miami University strengthened the Presbyterian cause. The origin of this church is traceable to a dispute occurring in the Presbyterian church of Bath . The Congregationalists, who partly composed it, revolted against the highhanded measures of Archibald Craig, a former appointee of the American Home Missionary Society, who became the pastor in 1833. Founded in 1822, the Presbyterian church in Bath had recently enjoyed the pastoral labors of one Peter Crocker, a Congregationalist from Falmouth, Massachusetts , who had come West for his health, bought a farm in this vicinity and preached by leave of the Oxford Presbytery. Craig, an Old School Presbyterian, did not take kindly to these arrangements. Permitting jealousy to run away with his reason, he literally bolted the church doors against the Congregationalists after he had agitated in the church session
hoped we who are toiling here to lay the foundations would receive by immigration after our Canal was opened. Thus far I have not had one good helper in all that have come in these three years past. Almost all the help of that kind as yet pass us by and go on to Wisconsin or Michigan ." This letter is in the American Home Missionary Society Papers.
13 John M. Dickey, A Brief History of the Presbyterian Church in the State of Indiana ( Madison , Indiana, 1828), 16–18; Hanford A. Ed-son, Contributions to the Early History of the Presbyterian Church in Indiana…. ( Cincinnati . Ohio . 1898). I, 255–258.
14 Nathaniel A. Hyde, Congregationalism in Indiana ( Indianapolis , Indiana, 1895), 15, 19.
the troublesome question of excommunicating them. Failing to dampen the ardor of his rivals, Craig had to content himself with preaching to the small Presbyterian remnant while Crocker continued as the pastor over the Congregationalists, who organized their own church and erected a house of worship 30 x 50 feet in size. When Moses H. Wilder became the pastor in 1836, the Bath Congregational church was strong and healthy. It aided in organizing the First Congregational Association of Indiana in 1837.15

Wilder soon found himself laden with responsibilities, not only as the Association scribe, but as the pastor of two other small Congregational churches in the region. One of these was at Fairfield , the other was on Sand Creek in Decatur County. Another Congregational church was organized in Decatur County out of "the better half" of the Presbyterian church organized earlier by Samuel G. Lowry, who had recently been transferred to Crawfordsville as the home missionary agent for northern Indiana. Here Presbyterianism of the Old School struggled to maintain itself against the Congregationalism of a few New Englanders who were dissatisfied with the party strife in the General Assembly. Although it was shortlived, the Indiana Association was a direct challenge to Presbyterianism. As Wilder said,

quote.p:
The association met [and] appointed a standing committee of missions who through their scribe shall be a medium [of] correspondence with the Am. Home Miss. Society respecting applications for aid from the churches within our bounds [in order] that we may make our applications
15 August J. Reifel, History of Franklin County , Indiana ( Indianapolis , Indiana, 1915), 447–448; Atlas of Franklin Co., Indiana,… ( Chicago , 1882), 41, 101; Atlas of Union County, Indiana,… ( Chicago , 1884), 15, 40, 69; James H. Rodabaugh, Robert Hamilton Bishop in Ohio Historical Collections, IV ( Columbus, Ohio , 1935), 97–115; Moses H. Wilder, Bath , Indiana, to Milton Badger, New York , November 21, 1836; application of the church committee to the American Home Missionary Society secretaries, Bath , Indiana, September 29, 1836; Moses H. Wilder, Bath , Indiana, to Absalom Peters, New York , February 8, May 2, July 31, and October 30, 1837. Hyde mentions the organization of the First Congregational Association of Indiana in Congregationalism in Indiana, 37–38, and quotes from an old issue of the Terre Haute , Indiana,
Wabash Courier relative to its formation, but he fails to give the date of issue. An earlier version of the Hyde treatise was published in the Minutes of the … Congregational Churches and Ministers of Indiana … ( Indianapolis , Indiana, 1883), 27–42, without reference to the First Congregational Association. See also Matthew Spinka (ed.), A History of Illinois Congregational and Christian Churches ( Chicago , 1944), 61–63 for a brief statement of the significance of the revolt against the Plan of Union being participated in by Congregationalists in Indiana, Michigan , and Illinois .
direct to your committee instead of going through a Presbyterian channel when there is sometimes a strong feeling against the name we bear.16

div.p: The fortunes of Congregationalism were dealt a heavy blow when Wilder left his field for Ohio in 1839.17

row.cell: Evangelical Association of the Wabash Valley ( Terre Haute Association)
Evangelical Association of Southern Indiana and Illinois

div.p:
The Terre Haute Church, founded December 30, 1834,18 did not immediately regard itself as a Congregational church, since all seventeen of its charter members were Presbyterians. The pastor, Mark A. Jewett, was a Methodist who hailed from
16 Moses H. Wilder, Bath , Indiana, to Absalom Peters, New York , July 31, 1837, in American Home Missionary Society Papers.
17 Moses H. Wilder, Fairfield , Indiana, to Milton Badger and American Home Missionary Society secretaries, New York , January 24, April 3, May 28, August 1, and December 10, 1838; Moses H. Wilder, Batavia, Clermont County, Ohio , to Milton Badger, New York , April 7, 1839; Samuel G. Lowry, Crawfordsville , Indiana, to Milton Badger, New York , August 8 and August 24, 1838; Ransom Hawley, Blooming-ton, Indiana, to Milton Badger, New York , August 20, 1838. All these letters deal with the fortunes of the infant Congregational churches and the First Congregational Association of Indiana.
18 There was Presbyterian preaching in Terre Haute before the organization of this independent church. J. R. Wheelock, grandson of Professor Eleazer Wheelock of Dartmouth College fame, had removed there from Decatur County in 1833 after experiencing "a spirit of persicution [sic] from Old School Presbyterians." "I was arraigned before the Presbytery there," he said, "condemned for preaching New England divinity—but the Synod reversed the sentence last Oct. While under this cloud I removed to this place, & sustained myself & family by teaching a Seminary here & what little I could get for preaching. Last April I gave up the Seminary & now devote myself exclusively to my appropriate work as a minister. My trial has produced a good effect on the cause of Truth in the State & I hope has in some measure been sanctified to myself. This is an interesting place, large & growing delightfully situated on the Wabash where the Cumberland or National Road crosses—with a beautiful prairie around it—but in a moral point of view every thing is the reverse. A little feeble church & they divided, & without much moral courage—the people generally enter-prizing, intelligent & bent on pleasure & money making—disposed to do but little for the support of the Gospel." J. R. Wheelock, Terre Haute , Indiana, to his cousins, the Misses Sarah, Ruth or Mary Patten Old Court House Street, Hartford , Conn., June 20, 1834. This letter is
Massachusetts .19 Yet all favored Congregationalism20 and supported the nearby undertakings of the American Home Missionary Society.21

The church at Michigan City in its beginnings was a Plan-of-Union church, consisting of nine members. It was formed in May, 1835,22 by John Morrill, a Presbyterian minister who had previously served under the American Home Missionary Society in southeastern Indiana, who later formed the First Congregational Church of Rockford, Illinois (1837), and still later organized other Congregational churches in the northern section of that state. By 1841 internal dissensions between the Presbyterians and the Congregationalists had virtually wrecked the church at "the City," but out of this struggle came a new organization which gave the Congregationalists the autonomy they were seeking. By the end of the 1840's this was a strong church.23 The Western Congregational Convention was held in its rooms in 1846.24

Another Congregational church was organized by a band of New Englandem in Richmond , early in 1835.25 So desperate was the struggle for survival, however, that by 1839 the resources of the church were entirely exhausted and the few remaining members joined the New School Presbyterian church formed meanwhile as the result of the schism in the
in the William Henry Smith Memorial Library of the Indiana Historical Society, Indianapolis , Indiana.
Following the excision of the four synods by the Presbyterian General Assembly in 1837, Wheelock wrote of his feeling "a strong reaction in this section … Scarcely a member of this Presby. (Craw-fordsville) can be found to advocate those unprecedented proceedings. Many who were on the fence will henceforth be decided against the measures of that immortal Assembly." J. R. Wheelock, Greencastle , Indiana, to Absalom Peters, New York , August 8, 1837.
19 Data supplied by Albert A. Faurot, Church Clerk. The letter is filed in the Hammond Library, Chicago Theological Seminary, Chicago, Illinois .
20 Hyde, Congregationalism in Indiana, 27–29.
21 Especially encouraged by the Terre Haute people was the work of Dean Andrews, pastor of the Congregational church in Marshall, Illinois , a few miles distant.
22 John Morrill, Michigan City, Indiana, to Absalom Peters, New York , February 10, 1836, in the American Home Missionary Society Papers.
23 The letters of Erastus Colton cited previously.
24 Minutes of the Western Congregational Convention, held at Michigan City, Indiana, July 30—August 2, 1846 ( New York , 1878).
25 Application of the church to the American Home Missionary Society Executive Committee, June 3, 1836; Peter Crocker, Richmond , Indiana, to Absalom Peters, New York , October 12, 1836.
General Assembly. It was reliably reported that illness and removals, the influence of the Baptists, the Presbyterians, and the Episcopalians (to say nothing of the "godless remainder of the two thousand inhabitants" of Richmond ) combined with the after-effects of the Panic of 1837 to snuff out the existence of this promising Congregational organization.26

Two churches were organized on the Plan of Union (Or-land and Ontario , both being affiliated with the Presbytery of St. Joseph ), in 1836 and 1840, respectively. The Ontario church had become Congregational in 1843,27 and the Orland church changed to the Congregational polity in 1842.28

Four or five small Congregational churches flourished in the mid-1840's in the region about Terre Haute and were under the pastoral care of Welton M. Modesitt. Among these were the churches of Otter Creek with eighteen members and Lost Creek with thirteen members. There were preaching stations at Numa, Cloverland, and other points where the average attendance was about fifty on the Sabbath.29 These smaller churches were associated with the larger church of Marshall, Illinois , and the prosperous Terre Haute congregation in a body known as the Evangelical Congregational Association of the Wabash Valley, organized in 1844.30

Two churches fully embracing the Congregational polity were organized in 1839, one in the town of Boonville and the
26 Peter Crocker, Richmond , Indiana, to Milton Badger, New York , April 13, 1839; Andrew W. Young, History of Wayne County, Indiana ( Cincinnati, Ohio , 1872), 407.
27 MS Minutes, Presbytery of St. Joseph , 158. (Courtesy of the Stated Clerk of the Synod of Michigan , John Comin, Rackham Building, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Michigan .)
28 Jacob Patch, Orland, Indiana, to Milton Badger, New York , February 28, 1848.
29 Welton M. Modesitt, Terre Haute , Indiana, to Charles Hall, New York , March 9, 1847.
30 William W. Sweet, The Congregationalists (vol. III of Religion on the American Frontier, 1783–1850, Chicago , 1939), 22; George Punchard, Congregationalism in America (5 vols., Boston , 1881), 11, 274, mentions M. A. Jewett and Dean Andrews as prime movers in this "useful and efficient organization," but gives no reference to documents relating to the history of this body. The Congregational church of Marshall, Illinois , adhered to this body in 1844. A. V. Gilbert, The First Congregational Church of Marshall, Illinois , a typewritten page filed in the Hammond Library, Chicago Theological Seminary, Chicago, Illinois ; see also the application of the German Congregational Church of Indianapolis in behalf of the pastor, Charles Richle, a member of this body, to the American Home Missionary Society Executive Committee, December 10, 1852.
other in Ohio Township in Warrick County.31 As late as 1844, it was reported that New Englanders were still hesitant about entering southwestern Indiana. They were inclined to look down on the inhabitants of that region as emigrants from the South and feared complications over contradictory attitudes toward the slavery question. Calvin Butler , the missionary, stated that he could stand in Warrick County and look across seven contiguous counties in none of which had the American Home Missionary Society stationed its appointees, except the county where he had been laboring seventeen years. During his long stay in Boonville, Butler noted great improvement in the cultural life of the people. Yet he imagined how a pastor in his native Connecticut might feel were he to cast his eyes over its lovely hills and valleys and realize that he was alone in the service of Christ!32 A veteran Presbyterian minister, one of the generation of the pioneers who had been present for the constitution of the Synod of Indiana in 1826, John McElroy Dickey, also toured southern Indiana in 1843 in the interest of the American Home Missionary Society. He reported in great detail on the conditions, religious and otherwise, and his findings support Butler 's.33

After 1833, the belated growth of Congregationalism in Indiana was promoted alike by the laymen and the ministers. With the exception of the churches in Warrick County (which were always in a desperate economic condition), all the Indiana Congregational churches organized previous to 1850 were organized by a few New England families. The majority of the pastors of these churches had also been Congregationalists in New England . Whether they were Presbyterians or Congregationalists, however, all these pastors but one (Jewett in Terre Haute ) were sustained in the field by the American Home Missionary Society. This fact in itself is proof that the Society was endeavoring to act impartially between these
31 Calvin Butler , Boonville, Indiana, to Milton Badger, New York , July 15, 1841. The total membership in both churches was only fifty.
32 Calvin Butler , Boonville, Indiana, to Milton Badger, New York , September 8, 1841, April 1, July 8, October 18, 1842, October 7, 1844, September 15, 1846, and May 24, 1847. Fear of the Catholics marks the last-noted letter.
33 John M. Dickey, New Washington, Clark County , Indiana, to Milton Badger and Charles Hall, New York , August 9, 1843: "I have thought for some time of continuing the history of the churches in this state, but have been prevented for want of time. I think I shall commence the work. I can write the history of each church I visit whilst I am in its bounds." Dickey's two-volume unfinished manuscript, History of Presbyterianism in Indiana, carrying the story down to 1847, may be seen at the Indiana State Library, Indianapolis , Indiana.
two denominations. Yet it is also a fact that the organization of all these churches was due to the progress of the revolt against the Plan of Union with the Presbyterians, although here the revolt was less violent than it was in Michigan and Illinois . With the organization of the earliest Indiana Congregational churches the slavery question had little to do, but following the organization of the Free Synod of Cincinnati in 1847 some Presbyterian churches in the eastern and northern counties of the state united with that body or swung over to Congregationalism.34 Later, some Indiana churches derived partial support for their ministers from the American Missionary Association. Several of these men in July, 1855, organized a Congregational association in Jay and Adams counties. There were seven places in this region where preaching was held regularly every two weeks.35 This abolitionist association was given the support of the two small Congregational churches of Buena Vista ( Randolph County ) and Monroe Township ( Adams County ), in 1857.36

The Plymouth Congregational Church of Indianapolis was organized in 1857. The first pastor of this thriving church was Nathaniel A. Hyde.37 Soon there was a movement to set up a state-wide fellowship of the Congregational ministers and churches, and this organization was consummated in 1858.38 It was not long until its life was dominated by clear-visioned, vigorous ministers, Lyman Abbott among them. Although Indiana Congregationalism lacked both numbers and prospects,39 it did not fall behind other Western states either in the character of its ministry or in the loyalty of its church members who, however, numbered less than a thousand in 1858.

list.item: 34 James Boggs to David B. Coe, New Corydon, Indiana, August 5, 1852; James Boggs to David B. Coe, LaPorte, Indiana, October 11, 1852. Boggs states that "most antislavery members [of the churches and the presbyteries with which he was acquainted] prefer Congregationalism to the Free Presbyterian Synod." He noted, however, that some of the strongest Presbyterian groups were made up of Colonizationists even at this late date. In the vicinity of New Corydon, Boggs found an ultra antislavery spirit, but at LaPorte he found some Congregationalists among whom there was no ultra antislavery feeling.
35 American Missionary (10 vols., New York , 1846–1856), IX (September. 1855), 86.
36 American Missionary, second series (20 vols., New York , 1857–1876), I (July, 1857), 159.
37 Hyde, congregationalism in Indiana, 35–38.
38 Minutes of the General Association of Congregational Churches and Ministers of Indiana, at its meeting in Indianapolis , May 12, 1859, with an appendix ( Indianapolis , Indiana, 1859), 3.

div.head: Indiana Historical Society
div.p: The American Association for State and Local History held its annual meeting in Washington in October. This is the same organization that met in Indianapolis last year, In attendance from Indiana. were Howard H. Peckham, secretary of the Indiana Historical Society, and Mrs. Grace Osterhus, of South Bend , a director of the Northern Indiana Historical Society.

The Association voted to inaugurate a quarterly magazine for history teachers, in co-operation with Cornell University Press. This periodical is designed for national circulation among junior and senior high school history teachers, to help them to do a more effective job of interesting their students. Individual member dues in the Association were raised to $3, and institutional memberships were pegged at $5. The Association is making a determined effort to raise additional funds by selling higher classes of membership to individuals, local societies, and corporations having historical interests. The goal of the Association is to employ a traveling executive secretary who can help societies in each state become more active and effective.

The Association has also instituted a system of awards to local historical societies for distinguished activity each year. The society that has done most by way of providing good programs, issuing publications, gaining members, leading the community in historical observances, etc., is given a certificate of commendation. Another contest is open to newspapers, service clubs, patriotic, and fraternal organizations for their historical activities. The country is divided into five regions, and there are winners in each region. It should stimulate local historical societies to know that their activities are watched by a national organization which stands ready to give them recognition for their efforts. Indeed, the idea has suggested to the Indiana Historical Bureau the desirability of instituting a statewide contest on a similar basis.

The Association passed a resolution to submit to President Truman a request for declaration of a National History Week, which would focus attention on the work of state and local historians once each year.

Dr. Carl E. Guthe, director of the New York State Museum,
delivered a stimulating address on local museums. Having inspected many of them, he is aware of their faults. He urged the adoption of three policies. First, local museums should delimit their scope; that is, they should determine how broad a field they will attempt to cover. Naturally, the history of their own community suggests itself first. Then they should refuse materials pertaining to other parts of the world and even non-historical gimcracks of their own area. Secondly, he advised "good housekeeping"—the keeping of accurate accession records and catalogues and the use of enough storage space so that everything is not on display at one time. Finally, he recommended developing the community services of the museum, to schools, clubs, business firms, and others.

Other papers dealt with publicity practices of historical societies, acquiring and preserving historical properties, and with folklore. The 1947 meeting of the Association will occur at Denver next September.

div.head: Documents
THE INHABITANTS OF NEW HARMONY ACCORDING TO THE FEDERAL CENSUS OF 1850
div.p: The significant character and development of the community of New Harmony, Posey County , Indiana, make the following analysis of the population of the county and the names and census statistics of the people of the township of general interest. The tables on Posey County are included for their own value and to give background to the unusual conditions in New Harmony .

The statistics for the county indicate that the largest number of the people exclusive of Hoosiers were natives of the Southern states and that there were more natives of Germany than of New England or of the Middle Atlantic States (see Table I).

Because of the large percentage of adults from the Southern and Middle Atlantic states, and the age (see Table III) and nativity of their children, one is led to believe that a considerable migration from these sections to Posey County took place in the early part of the nineteenth century. It is probably true that the Germans who settled permanently in this region came in large numbers somewhat later. It might also be suggested that previous to the birth of so many native Hoosiers, the Southerners formed the largest element in the population. Perhaps they were in a majority. To what extent was the population above the age of twenty in 1850 typical of the population in 1830 as respects nativity? Although less than one per cent of the total population came from the New England states, one may assume that some of the New Englanders migrated to this county early in the century.

The distribution of wealth (see Table 11) according to the valuation of real estate tends to confirm the above conclusions. Although it does not seem likely that the natives of Southern states brought much wealth with them, they held in 1850 approximately forty-three per cent of the total. Since they formed less than nineteen per cent of the population, this would indicate a longer period of residence. It is also interesting to note that the foreign element ranked
second with almost twenty-two per cent. Since they came later. to the county, does this indicate that they brought relatively more with them or that they were more thrifty

div.p: The so-called society of Harmony had its origin in Württemberg, from a schism in the Lutheran church about the year 1785. One hundred and fifty families in 1804 under the guidance of George Rapp, their pastor, emigrated to America and settled in Pennsylvania . After nine years in America, the society had acquired considerable wealth and wished to find a more favorable location. Frederick Rapp, one of their members and an adopted son of George Rapp, was sent on a tour of observation with instructions that a healthy site, good land, water power, and convenient river communication were to be considered when making the choice. After traveling for some months, he finally decided on the present site of New Harmony and the adjoining country. The society sold their possessions in 1814 in Pennsylvania for one hundred thousand dollars and emigrated to Harmonie, Indiana Territory, then a wilderness. A tedious journey down the Ohio and exposure to the inclemencies of the season caused much suffering and sickness, and their number was reduced by death. Nothing, however, could prevent them from attaining an honest and praiseworthy goal which they had set for themselves.1

George Rapp and associates purchased their first land
1
New Harmony , Indiana, Gazette, October 1, 1825. Volumes I and II of the Gazette are in the Indiana University Library, Bloomington , Indiana.
of 2,435 acres in Posey County on May 9, 1814. Five thousand three hundred and seventy additional acres were purchased during the remaining months of 1814. In the next year 4,319 acres were purchased, and in 1816 and 1817 Frederick Rapp purchased 1,920 acres. Land was also purchased in the adjoining counties of Gibson and Pike in Indiana and White County in Illinois . After ten years in Indiana, the Rappites moved back to Pennsylvania . Frederick Rapp, to whom was given the power of attorney, sold for George Rapp and associates to Robert Owen approximately twenty thousand acres of land as well as buildings and improvements on December 10, 1825, for $125,000. Over 7,400 acres were sold to William Maclure on March 1, 1830, for eleven thousand dollars. The Deed Record Book of Posey County indicates that smaller sales were made to other individuals.2

quote.p: Thus we see a body of people [Rappites]—strangers to our country,—ignorant of our language—unaccustomed to our modes of agriculture—imperfect mechanics, and worse manufacturers—through the mere advantage of cooperative industry, acquiring unrivalled skill, enjoying the comforts of life, and out-stripping the computation of extravagant calculators in the acquisition of wealth.

It is a fact worthy of record, and one that should be well considered by the political economists of a free, and enlightened republic, that in 1804, the whole property of this people did not exceed 25 dollars per head; in 1825, a fair estimate gave them 2500 dollars each person, man, woman, and child:—an instance of accumulation in the laborious professions, to which history does not afford a parallel.3

div.p:
Richard Flower, who had been commissioned by George Rapp to sell the large Harmonist estate, came to Braxfield to visit Robert Owen at a time when he was disappointed in a number of his plans. Flower suggested Harmonie as a possible site for Owen to put into practical operation his plans for communistic colonization which he had publicly advocated for sometime. Robert Dale Owen states, "The offer tempted my father. Here was a village ready built, a territory capable of supporting tens of thousands in a country where the expression of thought was free, and where the people were unsophisticated. I listened with delight to Mr. Flower's account of a frontier life; and when, one morning,
2 Government Original Entry Book, Posey County , Indiana, 33–41; Deed Record Book D, Posey County , Indiana, 206–214, 310–311; and Deed Record Book G, Posey County , Indiana, 241, 294–296. These records are in the courthouse at Mt. Vernon , Indiana.
3
New Harmony , Indiana, Gazette, October 1, 1825.
my father asked me, ‘Well, Robert, what say you—New Lanark or Harmony?’ I answered, without hesitation, ‘Harmony.’ " Flower could not conceal his amazement when he discovered Owen was interested in Harmonie.4

Owen purchased approximately twenty thousand acres from the Rappites and entertained great hopes of putting his plan for communistic colonization into operation. He delivered an address on April 27, 1825, at New Harmony , and the constitution of the preliminary society founded on May 1, 1825, was published.5

A number of outstanding individuals were attracted to New Harmony and on January 26, 1826, Thomas Say, William Maclure, and Charles Leseuer arrived from Philadelphia to make their future home in Indiana.6 From time to time other important people arrived, but Owen failed to achieve his goal. His son Robert Dale said: "I do not believe that any industrial experiment can succeed which proposes equal remuneration to all men., the diligent and the dilatory, the skilled artisan and the common laborer, the genius and the drudge."7 An article by "An Illinois Farmer" predicted that a society founded on Robert Owen's principles would be a failure.8

Both Rapp and Owen made an imprint on New Harmony which, no doubt, not even time will be able to erase. Because of the very interesting character of the population of Harmony Township, the names of its settlers in 1850 are being published.

There were a number of interesting and important people living in Harmony Township at the time of the 1850 census. A few of these may be noted. No doubt, others who were equally important are omitted, but it is not possible to mention all.

list.item: 4 Robert Dale Owen, Twenty-seven Years of Autobiography. Threading My Way. ( New York , 1874), 239–241; Robert Dale Owen, "The Social Experiment At New Harmony ," Atlantic Monthly ( Boston , 1857-), XXXII (1873), 224–225. The autobiography of Robert Dale Owen was published in the Atlantic Monthly in 1873, volumes XXXI and XXXII. The paper entitled "A Chapter of Autobiography" appears as "My Ancesto;;," in Threading My Way. Two papers "At Braxfield and in London , and "Close of the Tentative Years," did not appear in the Atlantic Monthly.

5
New Harmony , Indiana, Gazette, October 1, 1825.
6 Ibid., February 15, 1826.
7 Owen, Threading My Way, 290; Robert Dale Owen, "My Experience of Community Life," Atlantic Monthly, XXXII, 344.

8
New Harmony , Indiana, Gezette, October 29, 1825.

div.p: David D. and Robert D. Owen sons of Robert Owen and his daughter Jane Dale Owen Fauntleroy from Scotland added color to the life of New Harmony in 1850. George Flower, who accompanied Morris Birkbeck in 1817 to Edwards County, Illinois ; Prudence Birkbeck Ford, granddaughter of Morris Birkbeck; Thomas Mumford appointed by William Maclure and Mme. Fretageot to superintend one of the departments of the industrial school; and William Twigg, an outstanding lawyer, were among the English who settled in New Harmony . Francis J. N. Neef, born in Alsace, was outstanding for the promotion of Pestalozzi's methods in America. It has been stated that he published the first strictly pedagogical work in America. Josiah Mann, who was born in New York a first cousin of Horace Mann, was a prominent physician who is best remembered for his untiring services during the cholera epidemic in 1873. His three daughters married into the Owen family. Several Frenchmen also settled in this community. As early as 1824, Achilles Fretageot accompanied his teacher to America and eventually came to New Harmony . John Ribeyre was sent by the French government in 1848 to buy mules, but instead bought over twenty-seven hundred acres of land in Harmony Township. Edward Murphy, a friendless and barefooted Irish boy, came to New Harmony in 1826 to find shelter. In appreciation of what the town did for him, he left large sums of money for the library and established a park. Edward T. Cox, a Virginian, who became the state geologist in 1869 spent many years in New Harmony .9

In submitting the names of the free inhabitants of Harmony Township in Posey County , Indiana, for 1850, no corrections in spelling have been made. Columns 1, 2, and 13 have been omitted. Column 1 pertains to dwelling houses numbered in the order of visitation, of which there were 339. Column 2 pertains to families numbered in the order of visitation, of which there were 354. Column 13 indicates those who were deaf and dumb, blind, insane, idiotic, pauper, or convict. There were two inhabitants deaf and dumb, one idiotic, and one blind.

list.item: 9 Biographical card file in the Library of the Workingmen's Institute, New Harmony , Indiana; Personal interviews with Mary Emily Fauntleroy on September 21, 1946, and Mrs. Jacob C. Miller, niece of Alfred Ribeyre, on October 19, 1946, both of New Harmony , Indiana.
